There are a large amount of items, with the levels changing every time you play, making it never the same game every time you play it.Pros- +Very good price for such a fun game+Soundtracks are amazing+Difficult, but not impossible+Large variety of levels+Large variety of items+DLC, Wrath of the Lamb adds such a large amount, it's almost like a different game- And in a good way.+Looks like a classic browser game, and not a hugely computer intensive game+VERY small download, meaning it should take you less than a good minute (With bad internet) to download+Not very computer intenseCons--Music volume I found could not be changed, only disabled or enabled-Satanic references, but if anything has religion references in it there is bound to be something Anti within itAll in all, this game is worth your time and I would suggest it.So long as you are fine with seeing religion stuff within it.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 27, 2014
												The Binding of Isaac is a remarkably enjoyable game, and deserving of much of the praise it receives. While implementing tougher Roguelike elements, it manages to retain the fundamental accessibility and shallow learning curve that hallmark the most well-received indie titles. This is a commendable achievement, and is probably what makes it a foregone conclusion that this game will be remembered as one of the best indie games of all time. But the game does have a very glaring flaw that is too rarely pointed out. The game is short and the dungeons are small, which has the effect of making progression and completion nearly impossible unless you have a lucky start. This is really the worst that can be said of The Binding of Isaac, though, and the game is fun and rewarding at least as often as it is frustrating and unfair. Make sure that you have a very solid handle on the base game before you even consider getting the Wrath of the Lamb expansion, as it ramps up difficulty considerably.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 29, 2014
												The Binding of Isaac Game ReviewThe binding of Isaac is a indie rogue-like platformer game about a child called Isaac and his crazy religious mother. It is a game filled with secrets and unlockable characters and items with 2 DLC packs. After playing The Binding of Isaac for a few hours I realised there was a reason so many people described the game as “Unforgiving” and “disturbing”, It’s because its filled with satanic references, blood and gore. Not only that but The Binding of Isaac is incredibly difficult, only after my first 10 tries was I able to kill mom once. My favourite thing about The Binding of Isaac would have to be the game breaking aspect. By game breaking I mean there are some incompatible items in the game which cause you to have infinite health or can help you to get every item in the game. There is actually a massive part of the community that has dedicated itself to finding game breaking glitches that can make them extremely overpowered; some of these people have broken the game to the extent that a single attack on any boss will kill them instantly.Controls and GameplayThe controls to The Binding of Isaac are basic. WASD to move and your arrow keys to direct your attack. You move around the basement from room to room, each room containing something different. There are normal rooms which contain enemies, gold rooms which contain power up items that will impact your speed, damage, health and can sometimes impact you negatively. You first meet Isaac and his mother in the loading screen for the game which describes their lives as being happy until she hears a voice from above. The voice of god tells her to kill Isaac and Isaac, hearing this, flees into the houses basement to get away from his homicidal mother which is when the games main menu loads.  The game is about Isaac making his way through the basement to eventually reach and kill the boss, Mom. As you make your way through the basement you will encounter multiple different types of enemies (foetuses, pinworms, embryos, flaming headless monsters and lots of bugs) which will all try to kill you.Graphics and SoundThe graphics for The Binding of Isaac were made to have a retro feel to them. They have options for the in game detail which affects the rooms you enter. High detail means there will be cobwebs and blood on the walls while low detail will give you none of that. The detail setting also affects the pixels in game so setting it to low will give you a very fuzzy effect while high makes it look HD in comparison. The music in The Binding of Isaac is very varied. The music changes depending on the floor and room you are on/in. The music keeps you focused while playing and can help you to know what type of room or floor you are on.  The sounds in The Binding of Isaac are very eerie to say the least. The squishing noises when you kill monsters and the screaming from bosses I found to be very unsettling when I was playing and actually impacted on my performance when I was playing. Replayability and MultiplayerThe Binding of Isaac is literally the most replayable game I have ever played; this is because of how unforgiving the game and how interesting the storyline is. With over 341 items and 178 secrets in the game you must replay constantly to finish the game with everything unlocked. There has never been a official multiplayer feature for The Binding of Isaac however the great community surrounding it has created a few multiplayer mods for people to use. This let you play 2 players with you and another person on the same keyboard and you can both move around and shoot and fight enemies. Although the multiplayer mod is good, I think it ruins the game as there is no balancing aspect to the mod meaning there is now2 players but the same amount of bosses and enemies.To ConcludeI found The Binding of Isaac to be a ridiculously good indie game. The complexity of the story line and the references to religion surprised me and definitely made me enjoy the game a lot more. At only £4.00 this game is definitely one I would pick up off the steam store, especially as it is now one of my most played games and it’s one of the cheapest I own, this game practically pays for itself in minutes. The games DLC is also worth getting as it doubles the amount of content that is already inside this jam packed game, it adds characters, items, floors, monsters and more difficult bosses.  So to give this game a rating I would have to give it a:•	Easy to learn controls ✓•	Gameplay ✓•	Graphics ✓•	Sound/Music ✓•	Replayable ✓•	Multiplayer  XRATED 5/6

												The Binding of Isaac is by far the most grotesque and insane game I’ve played.  It’s pure mayhem and requires skill and patience to master. You play as Isaac who had to hide himself in his basement to avoid being murdered by his mother who was told by God to kill him. You venture through 8 levels gathering items, bonuses, and anything you can wield to face your mom. No play through is same because the levels are randomly generated. It’s an insanely addictive game that has huge replay ability and it will definitely keep you entertained for hours on end.

content:
Posted: February 13, 2014
												Umm... I don't know what to say about this game. it's... Weird. But overall (Even though i played a little on this account, and about 250+ hours on my old account), it's a fantastic, evenly priced game. Gives a Lot of Hours of Gameplay (Reaching the Cathedral is HARD, and takes over 13 successful runs that take a crapton of time >.<), with Many (MANY!) Items that appear randomly through the many levels (Random as well, for Pretty much Endless Fun), And will make you Become pretty much a Tank to anything that comes after You. A thing that's also Impressive is that how The game itself has a Kind of Creepy and Morbid Gameplay, but also Really Fun and Bizzarre, and Still Holding up to Comic-Like Graphics. More things like Challenges, Character selection (Each with its own Special Item and Starting Stats), A Handful of different Enemies, Random Bosses Each Level, Collection of Items, A lot of In-Game and Steam Achievements (With Many In-Game Unlockables to be found), An Interesting Backstory of the Main Character And a Fantastic amount of 13+ Endings, Make the Icing on this Strange But Amazing Cake. Also, You can "Tear" Down Enemies. *Da Bum Tss*. Overall, For me it's 9.2/10.

content:
Posted: January 23, 2015
												Another beautifully composed game by Team Meat (Edmund McMillen and Tommy Refenes), a small independent developer who also created top hit Super Meat Boy. The Binding of Isaac strikes a resemblance to the original Legend of Zelda exploration esque gameplay through caves and dungeons, except in this title the main character (and arguable protagonist) Isaac ventures through his basement trying to escape his mother who is asked by the voice of God to make a sacrifice to prove her faith. The game implements great gameplay mechanics (which adapt to your style of progressing through the game to continuously increase the games difficulty), clever visuals, and a great plot to create an amazing atmosphere in a must have PC title.

content:
Posted: October 11, 2014
												I must highly recommend this game it's simple, fun, and challenging. Trying to get no-damage achievements makes me cry.. okay, perhaps sometimes it's more challenging than fun. I like it though, even then.. Not good for players who want every achievement in a game with low effort - it's not going to happen here. Getting most achievements will take a lot of time - but it feels so rewarding to survive.. and getting an achievement is even more so. The game requires a dlc to finish, still - it's quite affordable, WoTL doubles the game length, increases difficulty - adds more variety.  I feel a DLC is worth the cash, even for those who don't intend to 100% the game. Just be prepared, pick up and win won't happen, in fact it requires quite a few playthroughs to unlock all the items, including a few of the most powerful ones. Though somewhat morbid, this top-down adventure game has definitely earned a spot in my top 5 favorite games on steam.~ Good luck in this game, I hope you give it the time to grow on you, and enjoy it as much as I have. Definitely a 10/10 from me.

number of helpful: 22 of 40 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 13, 2016
												It was the Winter Sale and everyone was all aboard the hype train. Choo Choooo! I jumped on board.But after hours and hours of playing, I have to say, this is what Extra Credits was talking about when they spoke about the difference between a challenging game and a punishing game. In a challenging game, one is forced to rely on skill, sometimes within a steep learning curve, but there's a high risk reward factor because you know if you do a good job, put in the time and effort to get better, make the smarter calls, you will be rewarded with greater success. There is a system to master, not game or exploit, but master- and when you manage to, you feel like the Master. In a punishing game, like so, you can in one run through be given 2 power ups per room and 2 spiders to defeat per room or NO power ups for 6 straight levels, 8 monsters per room, and every chest gives you multiple bombs that chase you until they explode. Because the effects of the same actions can produce such varying results, the overall feeling over time is that your actions aren't what matters.The end result for me is that instead of feeling challenged, I feel Punished for playing. I might as well have enjoyed rolling a die. To its credit, this has better graphics than just rolling a die and lots of kooky 3spooky5me atmosphere to immerse itself in, good music, and decent controls. But I don't really care if it's a high-spec 120 fps HD sensory feast factory. If the end result is still that it's all a crap shoot, that half the time I should just restart until I get a better first few levels, then there comes a painful awareness the more one plays that the outcome has less to do with me than with all those die rolls.

content:
Posted: August 3, 2015
												I told myself I wasn't going to write a review until I beat the game. But after playing 3 hours of this brutal top down dungeon crawler I realized I may never write a review. With that being said, lets get right into it. The Binding of Isaac is a top down dungeon crawler game based off of a story in the Bible. The story goes is that there is a a man named Abraham who is visted by God himself and is asked to sacrafice his son Isaac. This story is a lot like The Binding of Isaac (Discount the monsters and dungeons). Right off the bat you can see that The Binding of Isaac is not just some regular top down dungeon crawler game. It has amazing art combined with a dark depressing theme. Each and every enemy you encounter will shock you, you will have to remember these enemies, how they look like, and their attack patterns in order to advance further into the game. The items are goofy and loveable. Now lets do some pros and cons.Pros:- Fantasic soundtrack that will always keep you pumped up for the next boss- Vague yet incapturing story- A large variety of enemies that will only get harder as you avance further into the game- Unlockable characters, somthing to always strive to- There are indeed multiple endings- Until you've seen all endings and unlocked all characters and collected all items, there is always replay valueCons:- This game is impossibly difficultI know there is only one con but that con is no joke. This game is hard and unforgiving. It's fun at times but it really does suck when you die right before the "Mom Fight". It has a deep learning curve and there is no description on any item you get, which means in order to use it right you have to look it up on the wikia. If you intend on buying this game there is a few things to know.1) You are buying a game that is difficult, and there's no way of changing that.2)  If you plan on really going hard at this game, there is some reseach and memorizing involed.3) If you are religious in any way, you may find this game's content to be offensive. My final thought on this game is that it's a well made indie cult classic. I enjoy this game enough to play it every once and a while but not crazy about it. As for the DLC and Rebirth, I do not plan on buying those anytime soon. 8.5/10

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												Binding of Isaac..Yes, the Binding of Isaac is one of the deepest, heart touching and emotionful game about life of a little boy named Isaac. It has many Bible references, those make the game more mysterious and interesting. Not willing to spoil anything, but it's more like how Isaacs life turned into hell. He just lived a happy, joyful and simple life with his Mother in a small house on a hill. But one day Isaacs Mom heard a voice from above.. The God tells his Mother to prove her faith in him by sacrificing Isaac.The gameplay reminded me a lot of Zelda games - Bombs: used to break rocks, kill enemies and cut Your way through closed doors if needed. Coins: Used to play slot machines, buy items and etc. Keys: Unlock treasure rooms and other locked doors. It is also a very random, no two runs are the same, random pick-ups and enemies. Variety of items - over 250 items! every collectible You pick will be shown on Your character. Make Your shots (tears) stronger by collecting those items to defeat more difficult bosses, make Your Character faster by collecting other types of items, to dodge enemy attacks and so on! I'm definitely recommending it! You won't regret! The soundtrack is also very nice and fits the game. Many endings will keep You satisfied to play more, even if You die (Death is permanent in game).But the game has a deeper meaning to it, wayy deeper, it is what it makes so original and very different, from the other games, even games from the same creator. Yes, it is sad and You'll understand it once You've beaten the game 10th time..Have a nice time playing this amazing game!-Circumflex

content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												This game is not for everyone. It's tough as nails and very dependant on luck. If you like roguelikes, exploration, and finding great combos, this is the game for you. Don't touch it if you prefer more casual experiences, if dying bothers you or if you don't like starting for the beginning on each run, without saves.Once you put that aside, it has a very deep meaning hidden behind those cartoonish graphics. The game will keep you on your toes, making you wonder what's next and how to overcome them. Even in adversity, a little of good luck can turn the tide of the battle, and making poor decisions is punishing.However, as you play, you'll develop new strategies, and find combinations and combinations of items that are going to help you survive the horrid world that is the basement. You'll get beams, lasers, chocolate and more to fight your enemies, which get increasingly hard. Even with bad luck, good reflexes and strategy will make you survive each run.

content:
Posted: October 15, 2014
												This game is hard. Very hard. It throws you right in at the deep end with no knowledge of any of the huge catalogue of items, or enemies you will face, or even the rooms you will go through, but it has so much replay value. I must have played this game at least 1000 times by now, and I'm not even close to being bored, or even finishing the game. There is so much variability in this game's randomely generated rooms, floors, enemies and bosses, and you feel a huge sense of accomplishment every time you beat that tough boss or get past that awful room, and if and when you get lucky with items, you feel unstoppable, until you die, start again, and are as weak and pathetic as you always were. Enjoy.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 22, 2014
												The Bnding of Issac is a (like most people all it) a Zelda-like dungeon crawler. Yep, damn straight that's what it is. While this game is awesome, there are a few things that I have issues with. Let's start with the good things, shall we? Okay, the art style is awesome! I love the cartoony yet dark feel this game has to it. While it is a game that is dead serious, it's pretty funny with all of it's power-ups (which there are a frigging ton of) and bosses. Oh and good GOD ALMIGHTY that soundtrack. The music is creepy and also very catchy. PLUS! Every dungeon/ basement or whatthe♥♥♥♥ ever is random EVERY TIME, making every playthrough different. The characters and story are cool and funny (and down-right terrifying sometimes) and the enemies are also creepy and sometimes cute-ish. Now, those 'bad things' I said earlier? They really don't matter; but here we go. First, it's a flash game; therefore, it runs like♥♥♥♥♥♥(for me. I have an awfull computer). The lag, yes, can really pull me from the game, but it's something I get used to. And finally is that a lot of the power-ups are kindda crappy. But all-in-all, it's a great game, and I can easily recomend everyone to it.     Final Score=8.75/10Edit: I got Windows 8.1 and somehow my game runs like 50% better. Final FINAL Score =9.75/10

content:
Posted: August 15, 2013
												Story: A bit dark and filled with jabs at religion. That doesn't bother me, but the game is definitly not appropriate for a younger audience and those who don't take religion jokes lightly.  Also, some of the bosses/mobs are a bit gruesome and distrubing (but I dont mind!!).The game without the DLC has about 7 levels, takes me about an hour (on a good run) to beat the game. Considering that I have more than 20 hours into this game and have only beaten it 5 times :C. The trick to this game is that death is permanent for your current playthrough. Once you die you have to restart at the beginning and pray for good items. IF you aren't accustomed to the perma-death scenario I don't reccommend this game. I enjoy it purely because of the flexibility of the levels and the ever-changing drops. This game is a great game and has a good price imo.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
												Top-down 2D dungeon crawler roguelike.A game that relies on replayability by giving the player different runs every time he plays through the game. By completing the game multiple times, more items and areas are unlocked.The game is structured through floors that consist of rooms, which are randomly generated and can include various things from enemies to special Items.Each floor features an itemroom that includes a passive or activatible item to aid the player in the rather hard rooms filled with treacherous enemies. If the player is unable to dodge correctly, he will find himself getting damages quite often and ending runs preemptively.To progress from floor to floor the player has to defeat the boss of each floor, who also drop passive items that increase health, damage or other stats.Since the release of Rebirth I would not recommend buying the original game, mostly because of performance issues related to the flash-engine that the game uses.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												This game is not for everyone. It's tough as nails and very dependant on luck. If you like roguelikes, exploration, and finding great combos, this is the game for you. Don't touch it if you prefer more casual experiences, if dying bothers you or if you don't like starting for the beginning on each run, without saves.Once you put that aside, it has a very deep meaning hidden behind those cartoonish graphics. The game will keep you on your toes, making you wonder what's next and how to overcome them. Even in adversity, a little of good luck can turn the tide of the battle, and making poor decisions is punishing.However, as you play, you'll develop new strategies, and find combinations and combinations of items that are going to help you survive the horrid world that is the basement. You'll get beams, lasers, chocolate and more to fight your enemies, which get increasingly hard. Even with bad luck, good reflexes and strategy will make you survive each run.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												 Little late to the party, but I want to try out this new "Steam Reviews" thing by reviewing The Binding of Isaac. Contrary to popular belief, The Binding of Isaac is not hard, more, unforgiving. Many will be turned off by the nature of reviews stating it is hard and requires much skill. I find it, however, more unforgiving than "hard". Yes, there is a difference."Well, what do you mean?", says random bystander awed by hearing other's analysis being gone against. Well, you see, anyone who has played The Binding of Isaac can tell you it is a randomly generated game. This aspect gives it a very nice value of replayablility. Luck is a key factor in this generation, so you want a "lucky" run. However, anyone with a lot of skill CAN beat this game with crappy items. You see, the challenge does not stem from its risky 1 life gameplay style, as you can restart and get better items, possibly a 1-up to give you another life, the challenge comes from the random generation and♥♥♥♥♥♥loads of projectiles. However, you can master this game. Like I said before, you can use your skill to beat this game with ♥♥♥♥♥♥ items. Some strategies such as Secret Room guessing, and knowing how to avoid certain items really helps a lot. The secret to beating this game is to be immersed in its content and variables.  "So what? You can beat the game if you take into consideration your knowledge of this game. What makes you think more people will buy it?", says a bystander who keeps getting owned by Peeps. Well, you see, The Binding of Isaac has had a reputation for being an infamously hard game. The real ironic thing is, people can beat it in their first few runs. Then more content unlocks, and they gradually keep becoming better at the game. The game is not hard, its just a thing you can't plow through. I hope this will help people off put by the game's reputation as "hard" join in on the fun. I'm sorry this isn't much of a review, I'm really busy (With doing nothing) and I can't be bothered to write a full review. Though to truly know this game, you must play it yourself. Bye, and I hope to see you all again in 2014.

												The Bnding of Issac is a (like most people all it) a Zelda-like dungeon crawler. Yep, damn straight that's what it is. While this game is awesome, there are a few things that I have issues with. Let's start with the good things, shall we? Okay, the art style is awesome! I love the cartoony yet dark feel this game has to it. While it is a game that is dead serious, it's pretty funny with all of it's power-ups (which there are a frigging ton of) and bosses. Oh and good GOD ALMIGHTY that soundtrack. The music is creepy and also very catchy. PLUS! Every dungeon/ basement or whatthe♥♥♥♥ ever is random EVERY TIME, making every playthrough different. The characters and story are cool and funny (and down-right terrifying sometimes) and the enemies are also creepy and sometimes cute-ish. Now, those 'bad things' I said earlier? They really don't matter; but here we go. First, it's a flash game; therefore, it runs like♥♥♥♥♥♥(for me. I have an awfull computer). The lag, yes, can really pull me from the game, but it's something I get used to. And finally is that a lot of the power-ups are kindda crappy. But all-in-all, it's a great game, and I can easily recomend everyone to it.     Final Score=8.75/10Edit: I got Windows 8.1 and somehow my game runs like 50% better. Final FINAL Score =9.75/10

content:
Posted: August 7, 2014
												I passed up on this game a while ago because I wasn't entirely sure about it. Just a while ago, I purchased the game for $5 on Steam and started playing it. This game is extremely fun. There is no reason for anyone who likes games to not get this game. The game costs $5 and I've already played it longer than some $20-$40 games.STORY:You play as Isaac, a small child who has been thrown into the basement under his house after his mother supposedly heard a message from god telling her to sacrifice her son. You, as Isaac, must traverse the basement, going deeper and deeper in an effort to survive the horrors in the depths below.GAMEPLAY:The game takes place from a Birds-eye viewpoint, and you control Isaac using WASD and his tear shots using the arrow keys or the mouse. His tears can shoot in 4 cardinal directions (NSEW) and are used as Isaacs primary attack. On your way, there are secret rooms to find coins, shops to purchase items, treasure rooms to get new abilities, boss rooms to fight bosses, devil rooms to give up some hearts for a rare and special item, and so forth. The game has enough variety to keep me coming back for more and trying to perfect my "run".GRAPHICS:The game uses a sort-of cutesy vector graphics format, which works well in contrast of the dark undertones of the game. Elements and enemies that need to stand out do so, while things that aren't as important don't attract your eyes attention, something very important in games similar to The Binding of Isaac.BALANCE:The Binding of Isaac is well balanced, but it is easier to talk about what is not balanced rather than talk about what is. Tears Upgrades tend to be rather useless, as they are outshadowed in usefullness by their bigger brother "The Damage Upgrade", and the knockback produced from tears can go out of control with enough tears upgrades, sending enemies flying in all directions and making it harder to dodge. The game is also based on luck quite a bit, from the upgrades you draw to the rooms that you find, but it also requires a lot of skill, something you earn from playing the game. Additionally, some of the upgrades just plain suck. Other than that, the game is well balanced.OVERVIEW:The Binding of Isaac is a Birds-Eye dungeon crawler with a fantastic concept and huge buckets of replayability. This game would be high up on my Top 10 Favorite Games list if I had one.

content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
												First of all this game has a style and it is something more than just a dungeon & loot game, It has a spirit.When i started playing, the soundtacks and isaac's story impressed me, but it was really hard to play and i could barely survive 1 or 2 floors. As i played and started learning new things about the game (i am still learning in spite of my playtime) it has just became more and more enjoying because there are tons of monsters, items, achievements (most of the achievements unlock an item so it has a chance to drop when you unlock the achievement), and bosses in the game. When you die, you start from the begining, but it never bothered me because everything is completely random. Everytime you play, every single monster, every room, every boss, every item you get and even the alignment of rooms are different! The facts like there are 2 secret rooms every floor, or pills giving you random effects, or the devil and angel rooms makes the game even more exciting . Besides it is replayable-duh- when you finish the game for the first time it adds two more levels (floors) and more bosses to the game and when you finish the game like 11th time it unlocks 3 more levels (one of them is optional). The downside is, it sometimes really stimulates me to lose all those gear I collected because of a momentary mistake but I am really glad I bought the game. It is a ''must have'' in my opinion. If you haven't bought the game yet, I highly recommend you to buy it. And it is becoming a timeless classic.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 28, 2013
												After playing Super meat boy, I started looking out for new games by the same developer. Edmund Mcmillen’s wonderfully strange imagination is an interesting thing to explore through his games, that’s for sure.This game was not a disappointment. At first, I had no idea what to expect, the trailer was very strange but a tad intriguing. When I came across it there was next to no information about the game and the mechanics of it on the store page and back then there was no costumer reviews to go off of. Admittedly I never actually brought it to give it a go off of the information I was given, I ended up with it from a bundle and it’s the only reason I really played it. Although I wish I had taken the leap to try it because it is well worth it.Binding of Isaac is a randomly generated dungeon crawler, one I have heard to be described as Zelda-like you’re a young boy running from his demented mother. Who has been blinded by her hard-core Christianity and believes that the voice of god has spoken to her and told her to murder her son to prove her loyalty. So a very interesting concept, indeed.A short cut scene plays on start-up, which expands on what I just described, you find yourself wandering through randomly generated dungeon floors, fighting monsters, picking up loot and items as you go along that changes how you fight, gives you different abilities and drastically changes Isaac’s image. At the end of each floor, you fight a boss, and move on down to the next floor. It being harder than before, with a bigger space to explore and more enemies to defeat.There’s a large range of items to collect that when found for the first time is added to the “things I found” section in the main menu, so a lovely bit of collecting there to entice those OCD minded like myself, There’s new characters to unlock which vary in stats, challenges to complete and even some DLC that can extend your gameplay.You are given one life and one life only. You can find hearts to heal, but once you are dead, that’s it, you start all over again. So throughout the whole game and especially when nearing the end, it starts to put a little pressure on and gets that heart rate going. I’m not one to be good under pressure so it gets me every time. I FINALLY managed to complete the game a few times over, again, admittedly, only after I gained some “top tips” from my way-to-good-at-games brother. There have been people that have completed the game 10 times over and still not gotten bored. I think that the randomly generated dungeon element to it keeps its replay ability intact. If it were to replay the same levels over and over when you died, the game would be a lot different and no doubt a lot less popular. I have heard from friends that it is quite hard to complete without “doing your research” on the wiki or seeking tips from those nerdy minded like my brother who managed to figure all of it out themselves. I on the other hand find that kind of thing enjoyable, because it beats you every time and you work and research and try to understand the game more to finally get to that ending. I can quite honestly say that the first time I reached the end, my heart has never beaten that loud or that fast in a long time. And that sense of accomplishment you get from finishing a game, is a on a much higher scale when you work to complete this one. The music is great, it fits the setting perfectly and is great to listen to. Rarely have I actually wanted to download a game’s soundtrack, I can give most soundtracks a thumbs up but not often do I actually want to listen to game music outside of gaming.The art, as per usual in Edmunds games, is amazing. And I hear they are also looking to remake the game to have a more “retro” look, with possible multiplayer features. Which should be very interesting. For those interested you can look up “Binding of Isaac: Rebirth”.All in all, it is a great indie game, which is both fun and challenging. Definitely worth trying, I am not usually the dungeon crawler type, but this game is a lot of fun. The only fault that I had with this game, which has bothered me quite a few times now, is that I have lost my save for no reason. The game is listed as having ‘Steam Cloud’ features, but it definitely doesn't work. I haven't uninstalled the game, I haven't touched it. But recently I hopped on and seen all the progress that I had made was gone. And for a game that has no real save points or ongoing plot to keep up with, your stats, unlocked characters and collection of things you have found is pretty much all you have. I was pretty upset to see it had vanished and it’s something I felt I needed to warn people about. TL;DR : Awesome music, fun and engaging game with a slightly 'twisted' side to it. It's a challenge to reach the end and you can definitely end up putting a lot of hours into this. Addictive and awesome all around.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 14, 2015
												The Binding of Isaac is a roguelike game in which you play as a child traversing through randomly generated levels with the goal of stopping your mom from killing you. There is a large number of items that also randomly generate each playthrough that you can use to aid in your adventure. As you play the game, you unlock secrets and additional items to use in future playthroughs.With the Wrath of Lamb DLC, there are additional items, a new item type, floors (as opposed to levels), and bosses. The DLC also introduces challenges that limit (or otherwise challenge) you, which upon completion unlock new items for the main game. If you are considering buying The Binding of Isaac, I highly recommend also purchasing the Wrath of Lamb DLC.This game is heavy on both skill and luck. You will die a lot when you start playing the game. It will take many, many attempts to defeat the first final boss for the first time. As you complete playthroughs and unlock secrets, you will gain skill and new items that may help you in future playthroughs. The biggest issue with this game is that the framerate drops when a lot of tears (projectiles) or flashing enemies (flies), probably due to using the Flash engine. This is highly noticeable while playing the game, especially upon completing two certain bosses. It took me at least 10 in-game hours to get used to the wild framerate. Another issue is that the game may almost crash when it tries generating certain floors, which can be resolved by waiting for the program to respond even if the option to close the problem comes up.If you are interested in the game and would probably play this game a lot (tens and tens of hours), I would recommend purchasing The Binding of Isaac: Rebirth, which is a remake of the original game and DLC. A lot of new items, challenges, characters, enemies, and bosses are introduced. The art style is better (imo), the mechanics are better due to the change in game engine, and the game runs much more smoothly. The Binding of Isaac: Rebirth costs $14.99 normally. It is up to you on which you purchase if you want to.

												This game offers gameplay that will punish you for your major mistakes but allows you to learn from the small ones and that is where you grow. Most of the difficulty doesnt come from the enemies or the bosses bt it comes from learning how each item works and how to work with it because most of the items  you pick up you cannot get rid of ,meaning  that if you get an item that you hate you have to deal with it. Needless to say a wiki is a godsend when it comes to items and bosses beause some of the effects of the items are barely noticable unless you pay intense attention. Overall this game offers crushing but addictive gameplay , amazingly high replay value , and multiple endings making you wonder what just happened .

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 8, 2014
												One of my favorite games of all time!The binding of Isaac is a rough like game, where you have to go through a sereis of rooms, in order to omplete a level.The game is acually difficult, amnd at times, you will have geat challanges to overcome, like bosses or big pulls of enemyes.The story is simple, you are playing as Isaac (or some of the charectes you can unlock) and has to escape Mom, becouse she is trying to kill you in gods name. The story is not really anything that matters for a game like this, but it is nice to know why Isaac is running around in a creappy basement, full of monsters.The controles are simple, you can move in any direction, and you can shot in four directions, up, down, left and right. Along the way you will find upgrades, that can make you shot in other directions, shot faster, do more damage, gain more life, get friends to shot together with you and many more items.The funny part about the items, is that they don`t tell you, what the item can do. You either have to look at your stats, or try to shot, in order to see what the item did for you. If nothing changes, it can get really diffecult to find out what the item did, and you have to remember what meny items did, so you don`t end up downgrading youself.There are also tarot cards, that do diffrent things like clearing rooms, make enemyes take damage, teleport ypu and many more things.There are diffrent roomes on the map, that do diffrent things.The plain rooms, are just a figting room, you have to kill all the enemeyes in a room, in order to countinue to a nother room.There is a sacrifice room, where you have to take damage, in order to get an item.There is the a shop, where you can buy items for coins, this can be health, weapons, tarot cards, nearly everything.Then there is a secret room, where you have to bomb away a wall, in order to get in. If you don`t have a map that shows you where this room is, you have to bomb random walls.There is an arcade, where you can gamble, with your money and win prices.Then there is a tressure room, where you unlock the door with a key, in order to get an item.And then there is the boss rooms, and this is where the real action happens. To advance in the game, you have to defeat a boss, and the bosses are random selected, based on whitch floor you are on. The bosses can be hard, and some can be easy, but I would say they all are very injoable.So about the diffeculty, it is not only due to hard mobs and bosses, but also becouse it is a rough like game, if you die, you die, no countinues. This can get you very frusterated at times, but it is also the charm of a rough like game. You will end up dying a lot, and if you don`t have the right items, or haven`t found anything speceail, the game will punish you for that.The game has fantastic music! I love evety single track, and I promiss you will too! The music are very atmosferic, and they are good to psyck you up.This is one of my favorite games, it is fun, addicting and overall a fantastc game, thumps up. 8 out of 10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 18, 2015
												The Binding of Isaac is one of those games that grows on you. The first time I played Isaac I remember being frustrated and felt that I wasted two dollars. I never bothered to play beyond the basement. It's difficult for me to pinpoint what initially put me off from Isaac, but I chalk up my ignorance to an inability to progress. I didn't enjoy losing and quickly concluded the game was simply not for me. A couple years later one I was introduced to a livestreamer named LethalFrag. He often loaded up Binding of Isaac; one of his favorite games. While playing he often spoke highly of Isaac's replayability, soundtrack, and addictive gameplay. His praise helped me realize that Isaac deserved another look; and now I couldn't agree more with his assessment.  To appreciate The Binding of Isaac I needed to make some progress and unlock items. Dying stopped being so horrible as I faced each challenge and overcame them step by step. I understood that it was perfectly acceptable to lose; that's just part of the process. The trick was to pick myself up and learn from my mistakes. From there I was able to immerse myself in the gameplay. I've now logged over one hundred hours into the original Binding of Isaac and Wrath of the Lamb. I still find myself coming back for more. With the release of Rebirth I play the original far less often, but the newest "Eternals" update has got me back for what I expect will be another 100+ hours. TL;DR: The Binding of Isaac is unquestionably the best investment I've ever made on Steam. There's still plenty to appreciate, though Rebirth is now a much smoother experience.

content:
Posted: October 15, 2014
												This game is hard. Very hard. It throws you right in at the deep end with no knowledge of any of the huge catalogue of items, or enemies you will face, or even the rooms you will go through, but it has so much replay value. I must have played this game at least 1000 times by now, and I'm not even close to being bored, or even finishing the game. There is so much variability in this game's randomely generated rooms, floors, enemies and bosses, and you feel a huge sense of accomplishment every time you beat that tough boss or get past that awful room, and if and when you get lucky with items, you feel unstoppable, until you die, start again, and are as weak and pathetic as you always were. Enjoy.

content:
Posted: March 28, 2013
												After playing Super meat boy, I started looking out for new games by the same developer. Edmund Mcmillen’s wonderfully strange imagination is an interesting thing to explore through his games, that’s for sure.This game was not a disappointment. At first, I had no idea what to expect, the trailer was very strange but a tad intriguing. When I came across it there was next to no information about the game and the mechanics of it on the store page and back then there was no costumer reviews to go off of. Admittedly I never actually brought it to give it a go off of the information I was given, I ended up with it from a bundle and it’s the only reason I really played it. Although I wish I had taken the leap to try it because it is well worth it.Binding of Isaac is a randomly generated dungeon crawler, one I have heard to be described as Zelda-like you’re a young boy running from his demented mother. Who has been blinded by her hard-core Christianity and believes that the voice of god has spoken to her and told her to murder her son to prove her loyalty. So a very interesting concept, indeed.A short cut scene plays on start-up, which expands on what I just described, you find yourself wandering through randomly generated dungeon floors, fighting monsters, picking up loot and items as you go along that changes how you fight, gives you different abilities and drastically changes Isaac’s image. At the end of each floor, you fight a boss, and move on down to the next floor. It being harder than before, with a bigger space to explore and more enemies to defeat.There’s a large range of items to collect that when found for the first time is added to the “things I found” section in the main menu, so a lovely bit of collecting there to entice those OCD minded like myself, There’s new characters to unlock which vary in stats, challenges to complete and even some DLC that can extend your gameplay.You are given one life and one life only. You can find hearts to heal, but once you are dead, that’s it, you start all over again. So throughout the whole game and especially when nearing the end, it starts to put a little pressure on and gets that heart rate going. I’m not one to be good under pressure so it gets me every time. I FINALLY managed to complete the game a few times over, again, admittedly, only after I gained some “top tips” from my way-to-good-at-games brother. There have been people that have completed the game 10 times over and still not gotten bored. I think that the randomly generated dungeon element to it keeps its replay ability intact. If it were to replay the same levels over and over when you died, the game would be a lot different and no doubt a lot less popular. I have heard from friends that it is quite hard to complete without “doing your research” on the wiki or seeking tips from those nerdy minded like my brother who managed to figure all of it out themselves. I on the other hand find that kind of thing enjoyable, because it beats you every time and you work and research and try to understand the game more to finally get to that ending. I can quite honestly say that the first time I reached the end, my heart has never beaten that loud or that fast in a long time. And that sense of accomplishment you get from finishing a game, is a on a much higher scale when you work to complete this one. The music is great, it fits the setting perfectly and is great to listen to. Rarely have I actually wanted to download a game’s soundtrack, I can give most soundtracks a thumbs up but not often do I actually want to listen to game music outside of gaming.The art, as per usual in Edmunds games, is amazing. And I hear they are also looking to remake the game to have a more “retro” look, with possible multiplayer features. Which should be very interesting. For those interested you can look up “Binding of Isaac: Rebirth”.All in all, it is a great indie game, which is both fun and challenging. Definitely worth trying, I am not usually the dungeon crawler type, but this game is a lot of fun. The only fault that I had with this game, which has bothered me quite a few times now, is that I have lost my save for no reason. The game is listed as having ‘Steam Cloud’ features, but it definitely doesn't work. I haven't uninstalled the game, I haven't touched it. But recently I hopped on and seen all the progress that I had made was gone. And for a game that has no real save points or ongoing plot to keep up with, your stats, unlocked characters and collection of things you have found is pretty much all you have. I was pretty upset to see it had vanished and it’s something I felt I needed to warn people about. TL;DR : Awesome music, fun and engaging game with a slightly 'twisted' side to it. It's a challenge to reach the end and you can definitely end up putting a lot of hours into this. Addictive and awesome all around.

content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
												First of all this game has a style and it is something more than just a dungeon & loot game, It has a spirit.When i started playing, the soundtacks and isaac's story impressed me, but it was really hard to play and i could barely survive 1 or 2 floors. As i played and started learning new things about the game (i am still learning in spite of my playtime) it has just became more and more enjoying because there are tons of monsters, items, achievements (most of the achievements unlock an item so it has a chance to drop when you unlock the achievement), and bosses in the game. When you die, you start from the begining, but it never bothered me because everything is completely random. Everytime you play, every single monster, every room, every boss, every item you get and even the alignment of rooms are different! The facts like there are 2 secret rooms every floor, or pills giving you random effects, or the devil and angel rooms makes the game even more exciting . Besides it is replayable-duh- when you finish the game for the first time it adds two more levels (floors) and more bosses to the game and when you finish the game like 11th time it unlocks 3 more levels (one of them is optional). The downside is, it sometimes really stimulates me to lose all those gear I collected because of a momentary mistake but I am really glad I bought the game. It is a ''must have'' in my opinion. If you haven't bought the game yet, I highly recommend you to buy it. And it is becoming a timeless classic.

content:
Posted: August 9, 2014
												At first, once I bought this game, I thought it was quite fun, but quickly it sort of just became one of the games that I don't usually play. When that point in time is reached where you don't really feel like playing The Binding of Isaac anymore, it becomes a great game to play in short, spare time because of quick play. It requires you to really, not use tactics (doesn't help when you can't see what's in the rooms next to you), but to think about how you want to approach the game. This idea of 'approaching the game' includes: the character you choose to play (which affects much of how you play, depending on their stats) or the risks that you wish to take in the hopes of gaining a higher benefit. It might not seem very understandable in the way that I've put it, but any past players of this game should realise what I'm trying to say.This game has a lot to offer for players who want a difference and a challenge compared to other games. Nevertheless, the Binding of Isaac is a brilliant game and I recommend it to anyone that wishes to purchase this game.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2012
												If you liked Super Meat Boy, you'll love this game. The art style and punishing roguelike difficulty are attributed to the geniuses that are Edmund McMillen (of Team Meat) and Florian Himsl. The game is accompanied by the beautiful musical stylings of Danny Baranowsky (who also scored Super Meat Boy). Imagine Legend of Zelda, dungeons only, one life, with a dark, "cute-grotesque" art style. The more you play, the more items you'll be able to use. The more times you complete the game, the further you can progress. I can not recommend this game enough. Continually patched to add new things and fix bugs. The replayability is endless.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												The Binding of Isaac is a fun and addictive flash game well worth the price you're paying for it.I have already put more hours in this simple little flash of 5 euros full priced than in a ''Next-gen revolutionary'' game.The gameplay is easy to learn and understand and the later levels are always challenging.But all good things must have a bad side.Once you get an fair amount of items the game starts dropping in framerate which can be a bit frustrating.Also the game can get really easy or really difficult depending on certain item drops.Such as the ''Mom's knife'' and ''Sacred Heart'' combo which basicly allows you to 1-shot almost all enemies in the game (Including bosses).Otherwise it is possible to receive only activateable items which you can only carry 1 of at a time, resulting in getting no proper stats making the game near-impossible to complete.All things set aside I think it's a great game which is fun to play or watch others play.The price can drop below 2 euros during steam sales so if you need a fun game that's easy to pick up, look no further!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 3, 2013
												This game... Oh goodness, this game.The basis for this game originates around a small story in the bible, where Abraham is told to kill his son, as an act of obedience; His son's name, of course is Isaac. Upon almost achieving this goal, an angel stops him, letting him know it was merely a test. It is known as one of the most controversial bits of the bible, so I assume that's what sparked the creator's desire to make this game.Your journey begins when your mother hears a voice from "god", asking a sacrifice of her son to prove her faith. Isaac hides by dropping into a newly found trapdoor and finds himself in the dangerous pit of the basement. There, he finds what could have been, and what probably will be.This saddening and dark atmosphere is lightened by it's sadistic power-up lineup and cartoony artwork. Items you can grab will give you benefits and change how your character looks, often leading to some crude jokes. Terrifying bosses aren't always this game's goal, instead it lets the gameplay do the talking. Often you'll find yourself not properly equipped to face up a certain room or boss. It really drives the helplessness of Isaac home.You can do multiple runs of this game, with each one never being a copy of one before. Sure, the same items have a chance of appearing, but it ultimately feels like it's own unique run. You may be doomed from the start, or destined for victory; It all depends on your skill and luck.The Wrath of the Lamb DLC provides a whopping amount of content. It introduces a new item type, adds new mobs, new floors and bosses, the works. It's essentially a new game.This game is worth the full $8 to experience it all. Try it out yourself, you won't be disappointed!9.3/10 (Buy it. Now.) - WolfHero

												If Charles Manson played this game, he would definitely give it a 10/10What twisted minds did the developers of The Binding of Isaac have. How disturbing is a mother trying to kill her son who escaped to the basement, and can kill anything with his tears. Exploring the basement, you come across all sorts of horrendous monsters, decapitated cats’ heads, piles of faeces lying around and of course, your mother’s pads...among many other disturbing things.However once you become desensitized, this little game is pretty good. Going through each level, finding power-ups (or power-downs) to help you with the increasingly difficult monsters, ultimately fighting a boss to proceed to the next level of the basement.There is no continuity, so once you die, you start again from the beginning. Everything is randomly generated, so you will never have the same experience twice.It’s a really fun and interesting game, with alot of little references to other games -  You might find a pixelated pickaxe as a power-up, which of course, is Notch's pickaxe. You might come across a monster that spews toxic green acid, just like the one from Left for Dead 2 - and the list goes on.For the price you should certainly try this game out.My rating - 8/10

content:
Posted: May 5, 2015
												NOTE: Please buy the 'Wrath of the Lamb' DLC if you're going to get this. It will make TBoI a million times better, and will allow you to update the game to get the Hard Mode.With randomly generated dungeons for every playthrough and a top down dungeon crawling experience in the same vein of the original Zelda trilogy, The Binding of Isaac is a roguelike game that can be picked up for less than a dollar and provides hours and hours of fun on end.Following Isaac, a young boy who is trying to defeat his murderous mother after almost getting killed by her, TBoI has hundreds of items, ranging from the cutest of fashion accessories to the most grotesque parasites and diseases. With a randomisation system that makes no two playthroughs the same, TBoI is an adventure, a big step forward in the world of indie gaming, and ultimately, you'll have a hell of a time playing it.My criticisms with the game are that it's impossible to predict what items you're going to get, and while this adds to the mystery, this also means you can become obscenely OP or obscenely UP and it can become frustrating having to play through with what could be called a dead weight on your leg, which combined with the VERY steep learning curve, makes for a frustrating time with some playthroughs. Nonetheless, with a game that you can pick up for less than one dollar, where can you go wrong? I highly reccommend TBoI, and if you like it, go pick up the remake, The Binding of Isaac: Rebirth!

Posted: October 13, 2013
												The Binding of Isaac is a frustratingly-fun and challenging zelda-style rogue-lite, created by Edmund McMillen (Super Meat Boy) and Florian Himsl (Coil, The C-Word).The game features a ton of variables in the forms of characters, bosses, items, and power-ups, all of which can alter how much you progress throughout the game.With hilarious (and sometimes creepy) references to faith, religion, human ethics, and biology, Isaac is a delicious slice of blasphemy, served with a sour lemon.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												The Binding of Isaac is a roguelike indie game devloped by Edmund McMillen, which I have owned for a few years. It presents a unique stoyline, focusing around Isaac, a small boy who it is presumed wishes for his mother's affection. As the game has a heavy religion focus, a god speaks to his mother with the order to end Isaac's life. Isaac, fearful of his mother finds a hidden trapdoor in his room, and delves into the depths of what is under the house. The game itself is mainly skill based, but partially luck based. Certain combinations of items can ensure an easy and victorious playthrough while other item comboes make a challenging and tedious one.  It contains endless tilesets aswell as a total of 11 different settings along with 7 characters. This game is insanely fun, and provides a testament to your dodging skills. There are many more positive things I can say about this game, but I advise you pick it up and find out yourself ;)

content:
Posted: May 3, 2013
												This game... Oh goodness, this game.The basis for this game originates around a small story in the bible, where Abraham is told to kill his son, as an act of obedience; His son's name, of course is Isaac. Upon almost achieving this goal, an angel stops him, letting him know it was merely a test. It is known as one of the most controversial bits of the bible, so I assume that's what sparked the creator's desire to make this game.Your journey begins when your mother hears a voice from "god", asking a sacrifice of her son to prove her faith. Isaac hides by dropping into a newly found trapdoor and finds himself in the dangerous pit of the basement. There, he finds what could have been, and what probably will be.This saddening and dark atmosphere is lightened by it's sadistic power-up lineup and cartoony artwork. Items you can grab will give you benefits and change how your character looks, often leading to some crude jokes. Terrifying bosses aren't always this game's goal, instead it lets the gameplay do the talking. Often you'll find yourself not properly equipped to face up a certain room or boss. It really drives the helplessness of Isaac home.You can do multiple runs of this game, with each one never being a copy of one before. Sure, the same items have a chance of appearing, but it ultimately feels like it's own unique run. You may be doomed from the start, or destined for victory; It all depends on your skill and luck.The Wrath of the Lamb DLC provides a whopping amount of content. It introduces a new item type, adds new mobs, new floors and bosses, the works. It's essentially a new game.This game is worth the full $8 to experience it all. Try it out yourself, you won't be disappointed!9.3/10 (Buy it. Now.) - WolfHero

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												If Charles Manson played this game, he would definitely give it a 10/10What twisted minds did the developers of The Binding of Isaac have. How disturbing is a mother trying to kill her son who escaped to the basement, and can kill anything with his tears. Exploring the basement, you come across all sorts of horrendous monsters, decapitated cats’ heads, piles of faeces lying around and of course, your mother’s pads...among many other disturbing things.However once you become desensitized, this little game is pretty good. Going through each level, finding power-ups (or power-downs) to help you with the increasingly difficult monsters, ultimately fighting a boss to proceed to the next level of the basement.There is no continuity, so once you die, you start again from the beginning. Everything is randomly generated, so you will never have the same experience twice.It’s a really fun and interesting game, with alot of little references to other games -  You might find a pixelated pickaxe as a power-up, which of course, is Notch's pickaxe. You might come across a monster that spews toxic green acid, just like the one from Left for Dead 2 - and the list goes on.For the price you should certainly try this game out.My rating - 8/10

												The binding of Isaac is a brilliant little procedurally generated dungeon crawler in which you must make it through each level of your toy box in order to defeat your mother. content:
Posted: November 27, 2015
The Binding of Isaac is a two-dimensional Action-adventure Roguelike game, which preforms amazingly well in it's Genre. I will breakdown the components of the game:Story - 9/10The Binding of Isaac's storyline is based off the eponymous Bible story. Isaac (a kid) and his mother live in a small home situated on a hill, both peacefully keeping to themselves, with Isaac drawing doodles and playing with his toys while his mother watches Christian broadcasts on the television. Isaac's mother then hears "a voice from above", stating her son is corrupted and must be helped. It asks her to remove all sin from Isaac to save him. She obliges, and takes away his toys, games and even clothes.The voice again calls out to Isaac's mother, stating Isaac must be isolated from all the evil in the world. Once again, she follows its command and locks Isaac in his room. Finally, the voice speaks to her again, and tells her that she has done good, but it still questions her faith and commands she must sacrifice Isaac. She obliges, grabbing a kitchen knife and goes to Isaac's room. Isaac is watching through a sizable crack in his door and starts to panic. He finds a trapdoor under the rug, and just as his mother bursts in, he opens the trapdoor and jumps down it. Isaac then puts the paper he was drawing onto his wall, which transitions into the game's title screen.The game has multiple endings, all pointing at different ideas about Isaac's life.Gameplay - 10/10The ingame dungeons are procedurally generated, allowing endless hours of entertainment. It also includes random bosses from a list of over 20, 100+ powerups and items, and 50+ different types of enemies.Sound - 8/10TBOI has a great soundtrack and amazing background music which is highly attractive and creates a great atmosphere in this bizarre game.Overall - 9/10 FYI: I have played a lot more of this game than said by Steam as I have played the DRM free version.

content:
Posted: November 17, 2014
												tldr:6/10 - A rather mediocre top-down rogue action game with dark humor. I keep returning to it when I have a minute and I don't feel like doing anything complex or time consuming. Would absolutely skip if it wasn't on sale. Still very recommended at a reasonable price if you're looking for a simple casual game which is easy to get into.too long part:STORY - ?/10You're playing as Isaac - a little kid whose mom is nuts and wants to kill him, so he descends through a trap door in his room to fight his way through creepy places with creepy monsters in them.GAMEPLAY - 6/10- Simple but hard to master controls. Depends on anyones taste.- The game has its own economy and a SH*TLOAD of upgrades, active skills and consumables to be discovered. Each upgrade and skill is very interesting and fun to mess around with. While it's tempting to google what does what, it's way better fun to just pick something up and see what it does.- Levels are randomized and there is a lot of various monsters and bosses to spice things up. You won't play the game the same way twice. From this point of view the game offers infinite replayability, but...- The fact that everything is so heavily randomized prevents you from forming any sort of your own strategy. You just dive in and keep going until you win or die. Over time, this reduces the cool variety to the point where you're doing the same thing over and over again and it's only a liiiiiiiittle bit different because of some dice roll. - There is not much persistence to keep you returning for more. There are few unlockable characters and mandatory achievements but upgrades and skills are limited for each run where you find them. While it's nice to know that the game doesn't have you on a leash trying to unlock everything, it doesn't really motivate you to achieve anything when you start from zero every single time.

content:
Posted: September 15, 2014
												In this game, you play as Isaac, a child who is terrified of his mother. Mainly because she has heard some "divine voices" that she claims to be God, that are telling her to kill you. As a consequence, you jump into your own basement, scared of your own mother, who has cornered you. In your basement, plagued with weird monsters like flies that shoot blood and spooky skeletons. What do you do to defend yourself from these monsters? That's right, you kill them. With your tears. Your tears.This game has the weirdest story of any game I have played yet, by far. But all jokes aside, it's a great game that offers a wide range of achievements for any hunter out there. The rogue-like action apparently based on early Zelda games is great, and the DLC only makes the game much more enjoyable, long, and about ten times harder. I would reccomend this game to anyone with a few hours (or days) to spare, looking for an enjoyable way to kill time.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2012
												If you liked Super Meat Boy, you'll love this game. The art style and punishing roguelike difficulty are attributed to the geniuses that are Edmund McMillen (of Team Meat) and Florian Himsl. The game is accompanied by the beautiful musical stylings of Danny Baranowsky (who also scored Super Meat Boy). Imagine Legend of Zelda, dungeons only, one life, with a dark, "cute-grotesque" art style. The more you play, the more items you'll be able to use. The more times you complete the game, the further you can progress. I can not recommend this game enough. Continually patched to add new things and fix bugs. The replayability is endless.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												Isaac and his Mother lived alone in a small house on a hill.Isaac kept to himself, drawing pictures and playing with his toys, as his Mom watched Christian broadcasts on the television.Life was simple, and they were both happy.That was, until the day Isaac's Mom heard a voice, from above."Your son has become corrupted by sin! He needs to be saved!""I will do my best to save him, my Lord," Isaac's Mother replied, rushing into Isaac's room, removing all that was evil from his life.Again, the voice called to her:"Isaac's soul is still corrupt! He needs to be cut off from all that is evil,and confess his sins!""I will follow your instructions, Lord! I have faith in thee!" Isaac's Motherreplied, as she locked Isaac away in his room, away from all the evils of the world.One last time, Isaac's mom heard the voice of God calling to her:"You have done as I've asked, but I still question your devotion to me!To prove your faith, I will ask one more thing of you.""Yes lord. Anything!" Isaac's mother begged."To prove your love and devotion, I require a sacrifice.Your son, Isaac, will be this sacrifice.Go into his room, and end his life, as an offering to me to prove you love me above all else.""Yes, Lord," she replied, grabbing a butcher's knife from the kitchen.Isaac, watching through a crack in his door, trembled in fear.Scrambling around his room to find a hiding place, he noticed a trap door to the Basement, hidden under his rug.Without hesitation, he flung open the hatch, just as his mother burst through his door, and threw himself down, into the unknown depths below.And thus begins one of the best games I've ever played, on Steam or otherwise.In this game you play as Isaac (or one of 6 other characters who may or may not also be Isaac in different costumes, depending on your interpretation of the endings) and go through randomized floors of the Basement (and the caves, and depths, and maybe even beyond!), collecting all sorts of weird/gross powerups to eventually face-off your Mother.Even if you've played Rebirth, I'd recommend you pick this up, if only just to see where it all began.It doesn't run perfectly (since it was programmed in Flash it's capped at 30FPS, but if you're on a toaster like me, that might be more than you get on rebirth!The soundtrack is superb (and personally better than rebirth's soundtrack IMO), and the graphics just kind of work (it looks like it's all part of Isaac's drawings, which according to the first ending, it is)Pros:-Harder than Rebirth (due to mechanics changes and a lack of SUPER op items that aren't extremely rare to compensate for their power)-10/10 soundtrack (even just opening it up today i found myself subconsiously humming the title screen music!)-Spooky, but in a good way (ie subtlety, and not hamfisted jumpscares)-Replayability (especially with the new "Eternal Edition" update, I still haven't been able to beat some of those new bosses)Neutral:-Different styled boss fights than Rebirth (while Rebirth has a lot of bullet hell-type fights, BoI has more mechanical fights, for example, instead of shooting bullet hell patterns like in Rebirth, the 'true' final boss will shoot at you only when you shoot, matching your fire rate, and some bosses like Carrion Queen are more about dodging the ground hazards while making sure to hit her weak point. Some people may prefer it, some may not, it's mostly a matter of personal preference)Cons:-Fewer item synergies than Rebirth (Brimstone doesn't really synergize with anything aside from generic tear effects, Mom's Knife SORTA works with Spoon Bender and other similar effects i can't remember the name of in that the knife sorta wiggles in the direction of enemies, but mostly just keeps its same trajectory)-Lower framerate -No controller support (unless you use Joy2Key)One thing to keep in mind if you havent played it before, is that Wrath of the Lamb actually makes the game harder (by giving you a random chance to get alternate, harder versions of floors, and various curses that can help/hinder you), so if you're playing for the first time, you may not want to get the DLC right away, at least not until you've beaten the game a few times to unlock stuff.Also, you won't want hard mode on unless you're experienced with this game.Normal mode in this is equivalent to hard mode in Rebirth, so it's already decently hard.Overall i definitely recommend this, you basically have no excuse not to pick this up if it's on sale because the price gets pretty low, and if you're like me you'll probably end up with a ton of time in this game (ignore my steam played stats, a lot of my progress was offline or using SpiderMod/Community Remix mod, which is why i'm missing a few achievements and still have platinum god)

												Twisted comedy, endless replayability and hundrads of upgrades make the Binding of Issac one of my most played games. It is a dark twisted roguelike mixed with a layout lifted from the original zelda leading to simple controlls and easy to learn concepts with an ochean of underlieing complexity. Due to its random nature no two runs are the same and while I cant say the Asthetic is for everyone, if you are even slightly interested i would strongly suggest you give it a whirl.

content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												64 hours of nightmare... I think I'm lucky to beat this game to 100% in 64 hours. I don't even know, should I recommend this game? I think I should. The Binding of Isaac, an amazing roguelike game. The game's mechanics and presentation is similar to the dungeons of The Legend of Zelda, while incorporating random, procedurally-generated levels. Every room you enter, you must clear it if you wanna get outta there or put a bomb in front of the door that will do it too. Each floor of the dungeon includes a boss which you must defeat before continuing to the next level. Oh yeah, they have item rooms too. You can unlock new characters if you can get some achievements. This game has a lotta religious refences, oh wait, not only refences this games is about the Christianity. We can say that I suppose. So, this is the best roguelike, dungeon crawler game I've ever played. I can't wait for The Binding of Isaac: Rebirth. I'm ready for it! Buy this game and prepare yourself for Rebirth! Oh I almost forgot, this is a flash game so you know what it means. Whatever, just buy it!

content:
Posted: January 16, 2015
												If this game were a potato, it would be a pain-inducing, tear jerking, fly-spamming, guppy-destroying, lamb-wrathing, bloody-tearing, time-intensive potato. In other words, it's a well baked potato, with just enough bacon, and cheddar on the side to keep you entertained, with just a touch of that good ol' old-school feel that lots of games are lacking. You WILL die, that is not an option. And most likely it will be by the cold, cruel clutches of a fly.

content:
Posted: November 8, 2014
												I have had this game for around 2 years now and oh my god do i love it, When i lost my internet for over a year this game was the main reason i stayed sane, regardless of the fact steam says i have about 240 hours clocked on the game in actual fact it is closer to 1500 hours.The first ever time i played this game i hated it, i despised its difficulty and lack of explination for the items. It wasnt untill i didnt play it for about a week after my first time that i started to feel an urge to play it again ( it doesnt help that i was watching a lot of streams of a guy who played it a lot) and this time when i went back to the game i found my self enjoying the game, yeah i was still dieing a hella load ( i think i had around 40 deaths before i killed moms foot for the first time) but i wasnt raging about it, i was just thinking " huh so thats what this little bugger does well imma getcha next time mister"  and with the randomness of the items and the lackj of explination of what they do, i felt my self enjoying finding new items and figuring out what they do on my own, like an adventure, it was a sad day when i knew what all the items and trinkets and cards did.  For those who are checking this game out because of rebirth i highly recommend you get  this game and play it first, it is a great way to get the feel how the game plays and what it was like before we got them fancy pancy 16 bit graphicsReveiw word of the day : Randomness

												At first, you start a new game and die. Then, you restart, and die again. But each time you start a new run, you know more, you have more experience and have more stuff unlocked. So, with a bit of luck (as levels are generated randomly), you can progress further. Your runs are longer, you die later, you reach lower levels of the basement and discover more and more of the secrets (and there are plenty of them, believe me).Very addictive and rewarding game, I don't think I've ever played a game in which dying was so motivating to start all over again.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 18, 2013
												Edmund McMillen is a freaking genius, Part 2. (For Redux version go here.)'Isaac' is simply the best rogue-like I've ever played. Even with slightly more rogue-like experience under my belt now, I still love to go back to this game. It sets the bar freaking high.Released just under a year after Super Meat Boy, with a jumbo DLC expansion another year after that, the game plays like a top-down dungeon-crawler-shooter with randomised levels - no 2 playthroughs are exactly the same! (Unless you use a certain program that can pull the map seeds, but that's a different story.)The base game itself was very good, difficult at first but gets slightly easier as you unlock the more OP items and collectibles. The DLC adds a ton more content. Not to say that the items take away from the difficulty of the game though - some levels with the new Wrath monsters (and quite a few of the old monsters as well) feel somewhat akin to bullet curtain-like games.The only real gripe I have with this is that I cannot save my game mid-way! It's still a small flaw, and one that is corrected in its remake, 'The Binding of Isaac: Rebirth'. :)In the meantime, to circumvent this during super epic games, I recommend hibernating your computer with the game still running. Okay, well, my computer has survived the hibernation, but I'm not sure about yours...Well, okay, one more gripe - the game engine is in Flash, which is laggy at times and hard to play. For the most part though I didn't have any problems or let that detract from the fun of the game.If you can get this and the DLC for a cheap price, a must buy. It has possibly one of the highest ratios of time spent in game to money spent on game. (Excluding F2Ps, of course.)When to buy In May 2015, an all-new hard mode (Edmund M has called it names ranging from "Trololololol hell mode" to "Florian's ♥♥♥♥ You Mod") was released for owners of the WotL DLC - and it is hard as heck. You'll probably spend a lot of time trying to beat this mode with all characters, even if you are a veteran. Getting it on a steep discount will give you a lot of hours worth of gameplay for your dollar, but even full price for both game and DLC is not such a bad idea - Florian deserves to be rewarded for his new fiendishly unfair eternal manifestations. I genuinely mean that. It got me to re-look at, and re-evaluate, an old game which I thought I was done with.9.5/10
