												Pretty awesome game here.  This plus the Wrath of the Lamb DLC will provide many many hours of fun.  It takes a decent bit of learning what items do what, and you'll die a lot, but every run is a fresh take with new things thrown at you.  I really enjoy it and like a good challenge, but sometimes you can just get very unlucky with the drops you're given.  On the other hand you can get very lucky and feel overpowered until you go down deep enough and die anyway from a new boss you haven't fought yet.Overall though, pretty great. 9/10

content:
Posted: February 15, 2014
												A beautifully made game that is amazing in almost every way. Aside from the fact that you can't save, it is still absolutely wonderful! The graphics, design, randomness of the items and location, and the way it increasingly gets difficult. The Binding of Issac pulls you in. It is like an addiction that cannot be satisfied until the game is beaten, and the way that you cannot save just fuels the addiction more to beat the game. Imagine being on the last level fighting against the boss. You are left with only half a heart left and the boss with only less then 6% of health. Almost to the end you get hit. You die. Game over.Time to restart... Again.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												This game is so amazing. It looks really boring to people, but they don't understand. This game is so creative, and challenging! You expect so little of it, but it's just a huge game with so many moments that make you go crazy and so many moments that make you so excited and giggly. There are items that can touch you, personally, and they all have their own meaning. Each boss is different and the further you progress the harder they get. It has so much replay-ability as well! I got Platinum God recently, and it's still fun to play! The Binding of Isaac is by far, my favorite game on Steam, and maybe even my favorite game ever. You really should get it, it's such a journey, and it's so cheap. I can't wait for Rebirth, it's going to be AMAZING, just like this is.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2013
												A really fun game.  You play as a young child who constantly gets bullied by his mother.  He is ridiculed at school and everyone around him defecates on him.  The goal of this game is to progress through floors of your basement in order to kill your mum - the big poo monster.  It is fun to just chill in your house and play.  There is a wide range of items to collect in the game which help you on a run such as trinkets or cards.  There are also 5 characters other than Isaac which are unlocked via various methods.  Overall I would give this an 8.5/10.  The music and visuals are brilliant.  The levels are randomly generated to some extent.  The one downside to me would be that it gets repetitive but the range of characters can make up for it.

												The Binding of Isaac is by far my favorite game of all time. The gameplay  is smooth, with a bit of lag from here to there, but that really doesn't matter. Level floors are randomly generated. So many unique items, and such different ways to play. Besides Isaac there are six different characters to play as, each having there own pros and cons. The game is also mac compatible, which is great. The game is only 5.00 and the DLC is 3.00 dollars. I am amazed on how well Edmund McMillen did with this game and I can't wait for the remake!

												This game is great. There is a grotesque atmosphere when it comes to the games contents, but the controls are easy and quick to learn. Fans of the gameboy versions of Zelda will find this game to be very enjoyable. There are many similarities between the two games. The game is like a series of dungeons. Each time you beat the dungeon you get one of over 250 power ups. There is a lot of replayability in the game because of the different variations of power ups you can have. Each time you play, it is like starting with a new hero. You just have to make use of what you stumble upon.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 17, 2015
The Binding of Isaac. A flash semi-bullet hell satirical game on Christianity.The story goes that you are a young child named Isaac whom is stripped of fun and enjoyment in simple life after Mother has heard the voice of God demand that all things sin is removed. Hearing His one last wish from the high heavens, Mother grabs a knife and traps Isaac in his room, his only escape being a trapdoor leading below the foundation of the house. One powerful bash through the door and down goes the poor child.The objective of the game is the clear any rooms you enter of monstrosities that lie in your way as you travel deeper and deeper in the depths of your own basement, or maybe a cellar; crawling around the caves and catacombs, throughout the Depths of Nercopolis; and facing the one they call... Mom! Along the way, you find pick-ups, items, tarot cards, and pills that could do good or could do harm to Isaac as you take him on a somewhat sad (but fun!) venture to escape.ReviewThe GoodThough I had originally thought this game was kinda sad, I eventually got it, played it, and actually found myself excited over playing it over and over, unlocking a variety of cool items and using sweet powers. Aside from Isaac, you can also play other characters that have different starter abilites (ex. Magdalene, Cain, Eve), each unlocking a new item with every successful playthrough. If you add in the Wrath of the Lamb DLC, there are also challenges that start you out with preset powers and curses--another method of unlocking fantastic pick-ups.The BadIt is possible that anything kinda bad in this game were cleared up in the "sequel," Rebirth. (This portion of the review will be edited at a later time.)Concluding CommentsSeeing everyone (at one point) playing this game persuaded me to make an attempt to give it a go, and I do not at all regret making such a decision. The Binding of Isaac is an excellent action game that deserves the amount of support it has gotten. And Rebirth has done great justice. --Hermix.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6, 2014
												The Binding of Isaac. Top down shooter roguelike dungeon crawler shoot em up, wakka wakka other stuff. If you're into games with lots of RNG and a bit of skill as well as a healthy dose of morbidity then you'll probably want to pick this up.This game has some pretty solid controls, stylized artwork and great gameplay, but it's a flash game and as a result doesn't run super dooper well even if you have a beast machine.The basic plot is that you're a child and your momma is tryina keel ya. You jump in the basement...which the entrance is apparently in your room...and you go around killing the abominations that your mom apparently keeps stored down there. I can't really say much else as far as that goes because it would spoil the game...kind of...although that's pretty much it. Along the way you pick up random♥♥♥♥♥♥lying around and ♥♥♥♥ yourself up with it. Literally. At one point you'll probably get the coat hanger and jam it through your skull. I think the whole self mutilation thing is the most interesting aspect of the game because it's not overly done and it's an interesting way to 'upgrade' your character. It's visually fun to upgrade so to say.There's also a plethora of unlockables including different characters and mushrooms and alternate endings. This game has over 10 endings...shame they all suck. As far as that goes, most of the endings are generic 'unlock' endings and then some weird music. The ones that aren't unlock endings are 'left to speculation' which in my opinion is a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ way to be a lazy writer.The controls are simply. AWSD to move and Cursor keys(or mouse) to shoot. Shift drops a bomb and space uses items. Real simple and well implemented. No problems here.Each time you start a playthrough the rooms are randomly organized, but will always be square. The games not 'fully randomized' but follows the generic 'procedurally generated' system with pre built rooms that are randomly arranged with random monsters. Even the monster placement is static, but that's so the game isn't an♥♥♥♥♥to you and have a monster spawn on top of you I guess.Another great aspect is the soundtrack. It fits very well into the game with a series of 'darker' themed tracks. The best track is ultimately the final few bosses of course, but the rest really set the mood.There are quite a few uppies for this game and not a whole lot of downies.Uppies:Solid controls.Interesting graphics and graphical concepts(upgrading yourself by mutilating yourself).Great soundtrack.RNG is well put together.Fairly well balanced game.Memorable enemies and upgrades/items.Good AI (not great, just good).Downies:Overarching plot is lazy and overal just lame.Level design is bland even for a game that's supposed to be dark and dreary. (Just because it's supposed to be horror doesn't mean you can't have a ♥♥♥♥ING FOREST. SPLATTERHOUSE HAD A FOREST LEVEL AND IT HAD WATER.)Unique bosses are mostly just reskins.And that's it! This game was worth about 15 bucks to me, but you'll likely get it around 2.50 if you buy it on sale. I feel it's definitely worth the 5 bucks. As far as the expansion, it's more DLC oriented as it's 'more of the same', but it's cheap and also worth it IMO.

content:
Posted: January 16, 2014
												Binding of Isaac is a great example of a well-executed indie title that marries interestingly odd and obscure art and story references with engaging twitch-reflex  gameplay. It's essentially a twin-stick shooter with power ups set in an unique dungeon environment. It has numerous rogue-like elements as well. It's lacking resolutions higher than 720P, and when in Windowed mode it plays in a 4:3 square that looks fairly small on a 1080 screen. While in fullscreen mode, you cannot access the Steam overlay. Other than few minor gripes listed above, this is a fun little rogue-like twin-stick-style adventure shooter set in a level-by-level dungeon design.

content:
Posted: January 11, 2014
												I'll be honest. When I first saw this game I thought that it was one of the most stupid things I had ever seen. The artstyle looked childish to me and I found that it didn't match the dark atmosphere of the rest of the game. The fact that the main character is constantly crying seemed absurd and the gameplay looked boring and unappealing.But daaaamn was I wrong.Once you get the hang of the game mechanics (which may take a few hours) you'll really get addicted to it. There is so much to find out, so many different enemies, so many secrets, so many items with so many different effects.Each run is truly unique and the combat has an unexpected depth to it so that you will get constantly better which is again very motivating and fun.The game is difficult (at the beginning at least) and it is a bit of luck involved but that just adds to the uniqueness of every run and makes it even more satisfying when you get good items and have good run.The soundtrack is also just glorious and fits the creepy atmosphere perfectly.And the artstyle...you'll learn to love it. It may look very peculiar at the beginning but with the sick character design and the soundtrack it creates a very morbid experience which pulls you in again and again.It's easily the best rogue-like game I've ever played and it may just be the best out there.If you are intrested I suggest just give it a try. It's cheap, so you can't go wrong. It really has a lot more to offer then it seems and chances are high that, despite the first impression, you will fall in love with it.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 28, 2014
Run, Fight, Die, Repeat!In a few words, this would be the game. It's a weird rogue like, quite addictive little game. It's one of the few games where getting an achievement actually helps in-game, the majority of them are unlocking new items, items that you might or might not need in your "dungeon" exploring. Filled with a variety of items, which give you new powers and new aesthetics as well, every time getting randomized, one gameplay in 100 isn't even nearly the same, despite having the same levels, the maps and items are always random, but you could slowly but surly start figuring out some patterns, despite having a minimalistic tutorial at the start, you will be on your own after room 1. The whole game is a combination of LUCK and SKILL, both of them which are raised by EXPERIENCE (actually playing and replaying the game), it also involves some currency/item management and some though decisions, despite the lack of an actual inventory, you will gamble your way to the top or you will play it safe, the decision is yours.WARNING: The game uses flash, not just once it happened to me that the game would crash due to high number of powerups/items picked up during the gameplay, resulting to a laggy/crashy gameplay. I played it a while ago, I heard of an upcoming new version, not sure if they updated or fixed the current one.In rest, nothing bad that I could say about it, except that you will probably die a lot and it has good ambiental music.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												I bought this game for 1$ and was quite amazed about how interesting it was. Basically, you play Isaac and have to defeat ennemies and bosses in various rooms. You kill ennemies by shooting them with your tears or by "bombing" them. This game is a "rogue-like" : you go through doors, not knowing what you'll get, and have to find the bosses in the various different floors, along with the "item-rooms" that level-up your tears or give you new abilities.The whole game is RNG, every floor is always randomly generated and this is the main point of the game : no playthrough will be identical, ever, and that's what offers a great replay value.Another important thing : permadeath. If you die in this game, you have to start back at the beginning  (with another layout of course, since everything is RNG), and trust me, you'll die often. But each time you die, you learn from your mistakes and make better the next time. At the beginning, you'll be happy if you reach level 5, but at the end, reaching level 8 is quite normal. (Note : if you unlock new item, death doesn't affect that)[Pros] : + RNG all around the place = infinite replay value+ 2 minutes to get the point of the game and the controlls, 200 hours to fully master it+ A ton of items and stuff, you will learn something new at each playthrough and get better and better+ Items have synergies and can be "combined" for powerful results+ Awesome price for awesome game (under 1$ in sale)+ Will train your reflexes, strategy and learning abilities + Cool graphic style+ You can make it work smoothly even on a potato computer+ Simple controls : WASD to move, Arrows to Shoot, E to Bomb, Space to Use Item, Q to use Pill/Card ; that's all.+ A ton of "secrets" to master to get better+ "Humoristic" items with Internet Memes References (Lemon, Hoop de Loop, Forever Alone, Super Meat Boy...)[Cons] : - Hard at the beginning, can be very frustrating if you don't like the "learn by mistakes" approach (=/= die and retry)- The game engine can lag sometimes, the game isn't fully oprimized- Don't hope beating the "last" boss with under 60 hours of /played (but the game is fun even if you never finish it)- RNG land, sometimes, you'll get f*** up hard by bad RNG[Conslusion] : Anyone that is ok with games that involve reflexes should try this, at least if it's in sale for less than 1 buck. 10/10

content:
Posted: April 20, 2015
												note: I played this mostly offline, and have put considerably more than 4 hours into it.I know it's not a popular opinion, but I really don't like the Binding of Isaac. There are a lot of things to like about it, most notably the wonderfully grotesque design, but I personally hate the core mechanics. I really really tried to love it (largely because it was a game that was easy to play on the bus), but eventually gave up.Ok, so Binding of Isaac is a rogue-like, so we already know you're going to be dying and restarting a lot. That doesn't bother me. What does bother me is that you don't get better with each subsequent death. There's no lineage system or inventory hold over that helps you make a little more progress with each new game, you are just literally starting from scratch each time. And the controls are not complicated, so there isn't even an element of mastering the game's mechanics as progression.And then there's other major design decision that I hate, the complete randomness. Procedurally generated games can be a ton of fun and help to keep things interesting, but your success in each run of this game is largely decided before you even leave the first room. The enemies being random is great, it keeps things from being rote. However, the power-ups being random is a huge problem because of the disparity between them. Power-ups can be utterly worthless, or god-tier, and you never know what you're going to go get. But because your previous attempts don't have any impact, you're relying entirely on the much necessary power-ups, which are sometimes just going to be useless.One of my best runs was actually one of my first. In one of the first rooms I picked up a power-up that just devastated every enemy I came across. I've never been that lucky again. I enjoy challenging games, but there needs to be some sort of progression either through leveling or mastery of the mechanics, and Binding of Isaac has neither. There are of course going to be minor improvements to how you play, but for the most part, your 100th attempt has just as much chance of success as your 2nd attempt, and it's going to be based on what procedural roll you got. While this clearly doesn't deter most people, I find it to be an uninteresting set of mechanics that generally lead to wasting time on a run that was doomed to fail.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 21, 2014
												The Binding of Isaac is a micro dungeon crawler and expands itself the more runs you put into the game. It generates stages in a Zelda: Link to the Past sort of way, with a similair map style. I love the music in this game and the bosses are fun and grotesque. This game was pretty damn tough when I bought it, but it was worth it. It becomes easier and easier to get farther. Linux support would be nice, seeing there is already Mac support but there is no cause to complain. I can't wait for the remake!EDIT: There are saves for this game on YouTube, I lost my save due to lack of cloud support, added a save, got 9 achievements at once. It gave me the characters and such and saved about 40 hours of items I already had collected plus twenty more. In closing the worst fault of this game is easily fixed, if you haven't played it and use this technique I'd advise you not or you'll spoil the entire expierience. At 80 hours I barely have over half the achievements in this game, making it the most replayed game I own. Replay value seems nearly infinite.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												Binding of Isaac is brilliant. Each time you play the dungeon is completely randomised; the rooms, weapons and monsters are all completely different and so you never have the same playthrough. There's plenty of luck involved because if you don't get good items you probably won't make it too far. When you do though it is rewarding. You'll probably rage quit a few times and it takes a while to get good at the game but it's worth it, I'm hooked! The DLC is pretty good too but I'd advise getting seasoned with the game first as it does make things harder. More monsters, floors and items.. Everything you need to make each playthrough even more different from the last! Buy this game, because for £3.99 it's a steal, and if you can get it in a sale even better!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												Punishing, disturbing, tight, and atmospheric; I *LOVE* The Binding of Isaac! A huge mix of items, each with their own unique and sometimes mysterious effects, excellent difficulty ramp, gut-wrenching enemies and environments, and little touches that makes each new game a brand-new adventure. The art-style is very simplistic, but effective in evoking the twisted and disgusting views of an abused child. If you like punishing, randomly generated, visceral games, there are few that do it as well as The Binding of Isaac.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												Roguelike meets bullet hell. Another instant classic from Edmund McMillen. That name alone should make you buy it, but the game is so awesome in all departments: gameplay, replayability, nightmarish yet funny design, insane number of items which affect your character. I love it. You will love it. Don't forget to get the single DLC for more bizzare items and monsters.The only sad thing is that your PC should be decent enough to run it, though you wouldn't think that if you judge by the screenshots. This is because the game is made with Flash and is huge, so I can't play it comfortably (too much lag) on my cheap laptop I take with me when travelling. Too bad.Can't wait for The Binding of Isaac: Rebirth! It will rock!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												This is hands down one of the best indie games that I've had the pleasure of playing. There is so much replayability, it's unreal. The random spawning rooms, random upgrades, random weapons, no two playthroughs are the same. And unlike a lot of games released these days The Binding of Isaac is challenging, as there are no save slots and when you die that's it, Game Over... Start again. Add in the fact that there are over 10 endings, which all add to the game time. If you want a bit more of a challenge I'd also recommend buying the Wrath of Lamb dlc. This adds more rooms, more bosses, more items and increases the challenge tenfold.

content:
Posted: July 29, 2012
												The Binding of Isaac is a game where your mother is corrupted by sin and tries to kill you to please her "lord" and just before death you escape into a mysterious cave hidden under your rug. Within said cave you must acquire upgrades and kill ugly, vile, and probably smelly enemies such as flies, zombie headless things... And not to forget bosses. Some bosses include but are not limited to: Monstro, Larry Jr., Chub, and last but not least...*drum roll* Steven! As you make your way to the final floor you must kill your mother with all the items you've acquired. (By the way the whole game revolves around killing your mother for the most part.).Once your mother is dead you must delve into her "womb" and make your way to her heart. To wrap things up, this game is pretty Bad... BADASS! The game can provide you with endless hours of gameplay, so try it out, I mean really, it's only $5.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												When I bought this game on 2012 Summer Sales, I thought it was just another indie game that would provide a limited amount of fun until its gameplay were squeezed out. A hundred hours later, I am still addicted to its gameplay. Every time you enter the game, it is different; the objects you find (passives, actives, trinkets, drops), the rooms, the enemies, the final bosses; they kill you after 50 minutes, you end up with nothing. But you press the play button again, you unlock a new item you have never seen, you kill everything with your insane ammount of damage, you feel powerful. And you die again.Plus, its religious/parodical theme makes it even more appealing if you are interested in these religious ormystical parafernalia. (Do not take me wrong, this game is in no way supporting nor insulting religion)The perfect combination of fun and frustration renders the game the perfect choice if you want something cheap, not demanding at all, and with a simple touch of fun.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												Binding of Isaac is brilliant. Each time you play the dungeon is completely randomised; the rooms, weapons and monsters are all completely different and so you never have the same playthrough. There's plenty of luck involved because if you don't get good items you probably won't make it too far. When you do though it is rewarding. You'll probably rage quit a few times and it takes a while to get good at the game but it's worth it, I'm hooked! The DLC is pretty good too but I'd advise getting seasoned with the game first as it does make things harder. More monsters, floors and items.. Everything you need to make each playthrough even more different from the last! Buy this game, because for £3.99 it's a steal, and if you can get it in a sale even better!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22, 2014
												Okay, I guess since this is the most played game I have on my library, I've got some things to say about it. First of all, the game can be really hard on new players, but within a few hours you'll find yourself dwelling deeper into the depths of the basement (literally). The randomness of rooms, enemies and items you get each time really adds up for the replay, which is basically infinite. You feel challenged, sometimes a little unfairly, but most of the times, you're the only responsible for your success or defeat. It's very hard to put into words how much I enjoy playing this game. Each time you beat the game, it expands even more, and there's also challenges to complete, secrets to find, endings to discover, and to top all of that, a huge set of achievements to unlock, which will take your time very good. So, if you want a game that it's challenging, time-consuming and addictive, you can't go wrong for such a small price. And be sure to get the Wrath of the Lamb DLC as well.

Posted: July 25, 2014
												This game can be sum up into 1 word: "Awesome". Simple but tense 2D roguelike action. The randomness in the level design and item spawning makes this game unique each time I start a new run.Huge hidden item collection which affects the gameplay and the increasing difficulty after each completed run makes this game seems "grindy".The story is kinda messed up and take some time to understand the meaning behind it.The bloody and gory graphic makes it feels weird to play this game in front of friends.The minus side of this game is that it was built on the Flash framework which causes minor crashes sometimes no matter what spec of your computer. Hope this game would have a remake in the future.

												At first, I was contemplating Not Recommending this game.  It's frustrating, agrivating, and damn near impossible.  But then I stopped myself, because that's why this game is SO GOOD.  The difficulty gives it a level of replayability that is almost unmatched by other games, and the variety of different items, consumables, and trinkets you can find, the challenges you can complete, and the characters you can unlock only add to that addicitive quality.  Plus, at it's current price, with the addition of the sale that is taking place at the time of posting this, it's so cheap that it's almost a giveaway.  I mean 4.99, that's less than a footlong at Subway.  So stop stalling, hurry up, and buy this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												"If there are two people who I believe are going to save hardcore gaming, it's Hideki Kamiya and Edmund McMillen."-SelfCreated behind the same mind that brought you Super Meat Boy, The Binding of Isaac is a randomly-generated dungeon crawler with light rpg elements present and constant action. Set in a twisted atmosphere with dark themes ranging from child abuse, gender identity, suicide, abortion and how religion might negatively affect a child, you play as Isaac; a child who is relentlessly being hunted by his mother, who believes her son is corrupted by sin and must sacrifice him to prove her love to her god after hearing his voice. The game can be brutal at moments, due to not knowing how the game is played and randomly generated levels. However, the longer you play the game, the better you will understand how the game is played and where secrets are placed, what the items do and attack patterns your enemies display. It instructs you with trial and error gameplay and it's random but understandable level design. This is easily one of the best designed games I've ever played, and look forward to the remake of this game.Since this is a flash game,however, expect to have random framerate crashes, as the game is packed with so much content there will be moments where the game will slow down and may even stop responding.If you are a fan of the NES Legend of Zelda dungeioneering and/or a challenging game with a test of wits and reflexes, this is for you.

												YOU WILL DIE...not once, not twice but many, many times.  You'll get further...and then die again.  Then you'll get further still...and die again.  You'll find a bunch of pills and decide to try them...and you'll die.  After too many attempts to count, you'll finally make it to the end...and die.  You'll make it to the end again...and die again.  Eventually, you'll make it to the end...and...wait...was that the end?  No, it actually wasn't the end.  Then you'll die again.Binding of Isaac + the DLC is a deal at it's regular price but you can also get it on the cheap from numerous game bundle sites.

												Cute characters, grim storyline and basic gameplay combine to create a dungeon of treasures, literally.Fitting music and gruesome sound effects; the audio varies from funny to haunting, exactly that of the atmosphere.Not many games allow you to fart on your enemies or lay down a bog to no perceivable effect.Character upgrades are truly satisfying but come at a price, leaving you to decide where to compromise.Unforgiving with only 1 life, but with the random generation there is enough replayability to get past it, and with characters like these, it's difficult to stay mad at such a game.Some performance issues do strike during action-packed moments, how this is possible in what seems to be such a basic game goes unanswered, hopefully these issues will be resolved with an update. - Weren't fixed, runs like crap, what a piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥Overall, it's hard not to love at least one aspect of this game, but sick of people not optimising their♥♥♥♥♥♥

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 20, 2012
												Wow, I thought i had already recommended 'The Binding of Isaac'. Ok, so the video for tBoI doesn't particularily capture the games content, but its a dungeon crawler and throughout each play the ENTIRE crawl is randomized, from the rooms, treasure, bosses [There are tons of bosses] all the way to the decorations and whatnot. Music is fantastic, gameplay is solid (and easy to pick up), there's in excess of 16 endings or something like that (considerably more with WoTL), and completing a run just unlocks more treasures, bosses and floors (to not spoil anything). The Only downside is the inablility to save mid game so you've got to set aside a 45m set to do a good run. Regarding the DLC 'Wrath of the Lamb': A massive amount of content is added (see +=50%) which increases the general difficulty and overall variety and fun of the game for an absolutely minimal price. Replay value is magnificent and 'completing' the game will take a long time. As a side note, don't take the somewhat warped religious view and general violence of the game to heart and don't let it turn you away, it is meant for entertainment so getting all disgruntled over it is grossly unneccesary.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 24, 2012
												The entire concept of achievements is still somewhat controversial. Some argue that when used well they can add depth to games by giving you new ways to play, while others argue that they are nothing more than the human version of conditioning lab rats to press a button for a pellet (see: XBOX Live, Facebook Games). While I usually hate the latter variety of achievement, no game has ever made me into a happier, more mindless, lab rat than "The Binding of Isaac." It is entirely shameless in the way it uses items, achievements, and unlocks to keep you playing "just one more game." But despite being made in flash this is no mindless Facebook game either. This is an action rogue-like with real depth. The game play is fast and fun, while the randomized items are perfectly balanced so that in each game you will not only find something new, but also have to constantly make agonizingly tough decisions about which items to take and which to leave behind. One of my favs of 2011.

content:
Posted: November 4, 2012
												The Binding of Isaac is an amazing 2D roguelike game. It combines brutal difficulty, random dungeons, hundreds of items, and that classic Legend of Zelda feel into one really awesome and challenging game. It will take some getting used too, but once you have got the basics down, you'll have tonnes of fun playing this game.If you are good at running and gunning, you'll love this game... Now, just combine fast paced gaming, brutal enemies, hundreds of item combinations, random dungeon structures, and a wide variety of bosses, and you've pretty much summed up this epic game.8.5 out of 10.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 3, 2014
												Isaac and his mother lived alone in a small house on a hill. Isaac kept to himself drawing pictures and playing with his toys as his mom watched Christian broadcasts on the television. Life was simple and they were both happy. That was until the day Isaac's mom heard a voice from above:"Your son has become corrupted by sin. He needs to be saved.""I will do my best to save him, my Lord," Isaac's mother replied, rushing into Isaac's room, removing all that was evil from his life.Again the voice called to her:"Isaac's soul is still corrupt. He needs to be cut off from all that is evil in this world and confess his sins.""I will follow your instructions, Lord. I have faith in thee," Isaac's mother replied as she locked Isaac in his room away from the evils of the world.One last time Isaac's mom heard the voice of God calling to her:"You've done as I've asked, but I still question your devotion to me. To prove your faith, I will ask one more thing of you.""Yes, Lord. Anything," Isaac's mother begged."To prove your love and devotion, I require a sacrifice. Your son, Isaac, will be this sacrifice. Go into his room and end his life as an offering to me, to prove you love me above all else.""Yes, Lord," she replied, grabbing a butchers knife from the kitchen.Isaac, watching through a crack in his door, trembled in fear. Scrambling around his room to find a hiding place, he noticed a trapdoor to the basement hidden under his rug. Without hesitation, he flung open the hatch just as his mother burst through his door and threw himself down into the unknown depths below...

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 26, 2013
												The binding of Isaac игра, в которую стоит поиграть. Дайте ей шанс, и она вас еще долго не отпустит.   А теперь по-подробней. The binding of Isaac - творение Эдмунда Макмиллена. Чем известен этот человек? Вам говорит о чем-нибудь игра Super Meat Boy? Именно этот дядька ее создал. А слыхали о Gish? Тоже его творение. Не говоря уж о множество Flash игр, которыми он изначально занимался: Coil, Triachnid, Time ♥♥♥♥, Grey-Matter, Aether - все это создал сей замечательный человек. Но речь не о нем. А об Isaac. Жанр этой игры - roguelike. Каждый "раунд" в этой игре можно назвать уникальным так, как в игре множество вещей, которые вы по ходу игры находите и используйте. Вещи эти самые разнообразные: от простого гвоздя до эмбриона в баночке. Новичку это может показаться странным: "Гвоздь? Эмбрион? Что за ху**я?!" Однако, каждый предмет меняет/дополняет не только способности, но и внешний вид. Под конец игры может выйти страшный, черный, летающий, злобно улыбающийся призрак. А может и....................котик :3 По мимо интересных вещей есть не менее интересные боссы. И они заставят вас поплакать, как девочку, которая резала лук и смотрела Хатико одновременно!!! Серьезно, если вы умрете, то начнете все сначала. А боссы не щадят никого. Кстати, по мере прохождения игры вам будут доступны новые вещи, комнаты, боссы и персонажи. Так что заскучать она вам не даст. Не расстраивайтесь если не сможете пройти игру за первые дни. Ибо я прошел ее в первый раз только спустя 50 часов! Но, ГОСПОДИ, как я был горд собой. Эта победа сделала мой день. И затем пошло и поехало. Я продолжал ее проходить. А после 11 прохождение игра становится длиннее!!! Господи, я так и не смог пройти ее дальше(    Итог: Господи, ты должен ее купить. Она того стоит!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 16, 2014
												This epic adventure is endless. First it ends, then it ends, then it ends, and if you have the DLC it ends once more. I've enjoyed every bit of it. Once you beat the game on the last ending (the final ending) there is still more to do. Depending on your skill level, many hours of gameplay may await. The overall game is nice too. Every boss varies and requires different methods of managing to defeat them. The art is great, but it may make it look like a kid's game although its dark atmosphere assures it's not. Have fun crying on poop, getting eaten by flies, and purchasing pills from a hanged man!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2015
												Let me start this review by saying that I hated the game at the beginning so much that I wrote a negative review about it. I hated the bugs, the lags because of the poor (flash based) game engine and of course the ultra-hard difficulty. So why did I change my opinion about it? Well, I still kinda hate it but not in a bad way :)The Binding of Isaac is a game for hardcore gamers! Period. We all have been spoiled by the new(er) games with lengthy tutorials, huge amounts of hints and by a difficulty so easy that you're asking yourself if the game is made for kids. Not with this game! The difficulty is hard. Extremely hard! You need to have fast reflexes, think and move smart and if all else fails then only luck can save you. Even when you know all of the dirty tricks and moves of your enemies, there's still no guarantee you won't get hit and eventually die. It's always a challenge no matter how good you're at it and on top of that the randomly generated levels offer endless replay value.Long story short; this game will make you a better gamer overall. You don't believe me? Now hear me out. I just collected the final achievement called "Platinum God!" and the feeling is amazing. I feel like I can tackle and complete every game out there. It was worth every hour I spent with the game even though I was mad, frustrated, angry and in a rage quit mood quite often. Be warned though. You need a lot of patience, skills and balls of steel to beat this game. So if you're a casual gamer avoid it all cost.GG!

content:
Posted: July 24, 2012
												Much like Edmund McMillan's last game, Super Meat Boy, The Binding of Isaac is a game which can reach brutal difficulty, boasting dark, violent humor and unique visuals. Where Super Meat Boy was a platformer, Binding of Isaac is a roguelike RPG of sorts; a game where death is imminent and repeat playthroughs are not suggested, they are required. The levels, enemies, bosses, and treasure are randomized allowing for amazing changes in gameplay every run. I give this game my highest recommendation, but beware that it may not be for all tastes.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												Challenging, fun, addicting, and highly replayable.  I would recommend it to anybody really.  Controls are simple, items are unique and varied, and the art style is cute but at the same time a bit crude(in a good way of course).  There is a pretty noticeable problem when it comes to performance, since this game was made in Flash, it will lag like crazy during intense moments in the game. While this is a great game, at this point there really isn't any reason to buy this game over Rebirth now that that's out.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 6, 2015
												I guess I'm late to the party, but that this game is more than recommended can't be stressed enough.The Binding of Isaac is a roguelike with almost unlimited replay value, lots of black humor and a story skillfully told with just a hand full of spoken words.Playing through the game multiple times unlocks new items, levels and difficulties and the ride does not seem to ever stop. Other than many roguelike games, it manages to never get unfair - the player always has strategies at hand that can get him through the game. It may take him some (or some more) tries in the beginning tho :)Add this up with a lovely soundtrack and a DLC that doubles the already vast content and you've got a month, a quarter, maybe even half a year covered.There's just one downside: The Binding of Isaac Rebirth is now out - a remake improving on almost every aspect whilst also adding massive content. You may consider getting this one instead.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 21, 2014
												The Binding of Isaac is a micro dungeon crawler and expands itself the more runs you put into the game. It generates stages in a Zelda: Link to the Past sort of way, with a similair map style. I love the music in this game and the bosses are fun and grotesque. This game was pretty damn tough when I bought it, but it was worth it. It becomes easier and easier to get farther. Linux support would be nice, seeing there is already Mac support but there is no cause to complain. I can't wait for the remake!EDIT: There are saves for this game on YouTube, I lost my save due to lack of cloud support, added a save, got 9 achievements at once. It gave me the characters and such and saved about 40 hours of items I already had collected plus twenty more. In closing the worst fault of this game is easily fixed, if you haven't played it and use this technique I'd advise you not or you'll spoil the entire expierience. At 80 hours I barely have over half the achievements in this game, making it the most replayed game I own. Replay value seems nearly infinite.

content:
Posted: July 24, 2012
												Much like Edmund McMillan's last game, Super Meat Boy, The Binding of Isaac is a game which can reach brutal difficulty, boasting dark, violent humor and unique visuals. Where Super Meat Boy was a platformer, Binding of Isaac is a roguelike RPG of sorts; a game where death is imminent and repeat playthroughs are not suggested, they are required. The levels, enemies, bosses, and treasure are randomized allowing for amazing changes in gameplay every run. I give this game my highest recommendation, but beware that it may not be for all tastes.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3, 2015
												What a great game!I bought this game in the Steam Winter Sale, when it was available for 0,66€ including the DLC. I saw some gameplay-videos before, but never found it particularly interesting. However, that changed a few weeks ago when a friend of mine told me that it was quite fun. So I decided to give it a try for a that cheap price. What shall I say...? I have never been that addicted to a game in such a short time! It's an indie masterpiece.The Characters:You are playing as one out of seven characters. By default, only Isaac is unlocked, for the others you have to achieve certain victories or find certain items in order to unlock them. Each character has it's own pros and cons, so it's pretty much up to the player which one to play.The Story:Actually, there's not much story in the game. To sum it up, it'd be as follows (no spoilers, d'oh!): Isaacs' mum which is a strong believer in some kind of god, wants to kill you, because her "god" told her to do so. It is up to you to get stronger by finding items and unlocking more and powerful abilities (which come with items) to finally kill your mum. Voilà.The Gameplay:Basically, in The Binding of Isaac you run through small areas (called rooms). There are 6 levels until you get to the bossfight. Each level contains of around 5 to 15 areas. But don't let these small numbers fool you! The game is insanely challening, I'm hardly able to reach level 4 by now, and if I do, I was insanely lucky with the items. Speaking of items, they upgrade your basic stats or change something about your abilities. For example, you might get +1 attack, get faster, get a buddy who shoots enemies whenever you shoot, or get a stronger attack.There's a main attack (your tears) and a secondary attack, which is fired when pressing spacebar. The main attack can be upgraded by finding items, however, in order to get a secondary attack, you will only have one when you find a secondary-attack item.Except when using certain items you have one live only. When you die, you have to start at zero again, no items, no buffs, nothing. However, your HP can be upgraded or degraded, but it still required skill to beat the game.Information about the graphics and certain gameplay elements:Most of the items you'll find will mutilate your character. This sometimes looks quite gross, especially if you consider the young age of the main protagonist, Isaac. So if you're a squeamish person, you might want to take this into account. However, the graphics are in no way hyperrealistic, which minimalizes this problem I guess.Summary:If I had to use points in order to show, how good or bad the game is, here is what it'd look like:Graphics: 6/10 (awesome animations, everything looks sweet, but it's quite repetitive)Gameplay: 10/10 (insanely nice working, hard but fair)Story: WHO CARES?Addiction-level: 8/10 (I don't know yet how long this game will entertain me, but at the moment it's freaking addictive)Fun-level: 10/10 (this is very personal, ofc.)PS: There's sometimes a problem with the achievements, meaning you can't unlock them. Then you have to follow some guides in order to be able to unlock them. If you're an achievement-hunter, this might be interesting for you.

content:
Posted: April 12, 2013
Cry or DieA former shell of a boy turned lump-of-flesh, Isaac must endure the horrors of lost siblings that never came to be. These undead fetuses are hellbent on destroying Isaac's very way of living and are very angry, that is to say, not only at him but at his mother even more so. Mom receives a godsend message from the Lord one day, asking her to prove her devotion and faith by sacrificing her son, Isaac. Who knows if his late brothers and sisters suffered the same fate, but one thing's for certain, Isaac isn't going to wait to find out!Overall, the top-down arcade style of The Binding of Isaac is great fun to be had. The levels are generated at random each time, and knowing this, makes for high replay value... from an indie game no doubt! Enemies are unique in appearance, there are various items with special capabliities, and plus, you take down your foes by crying a surge of tear drops! Poor Isaac... more fun for us then!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2015
												Let me start this review by saying that I hated the game at the beginning so much that I wrote a negative review about it. I hated the bugs, the lags because of the poor (flash based) game engine and of course the ultra-hard difficulty. So why did I change my opinion about it? Well, I still kinda hate it but not in a bad way :)The Binding of Isaac is a game for hardcore gamers! Period. We all have been spoiled by the new(er) games with lengthy tutorials, huge amounts of hints and by a difficulty so easy that you're asking yourself if the game is made for kids. Not with this game! The difficulty is hard. Extremely hard! You need to have fast reflexes, think and move smart and if all else fails then only luck can save you. Even when you know all of the dirty tricks and moves of your enemies, there's still no guarantee you won't get hit and eventually die. It's always a challenge no matter how good you're at it and on top of that the randomly generated levels offer endless replay value.Long story short; this game will make you a better gamer overall. You don't believe me? Now hear me out. I just collected the final achievement called "Platinum God!" and the feeling is amazing. I feel like I can tackle and complete every game out there. It was worth every hour I spent with the game even though I was mad, frustrated, angry and in a rage quit mood quite often. Be warned though. You need a lot of patience, skills and balls of steel to beat this game. So if you're a casual gamer avoid it all cost.GG!

content:
Posted: July 11, 2013
												This game is amazing. I have over 100 hours logged in it and I'm stil enjoying it.PROS- Random runs provide limitless entertainment, no two runs are the same, there are a lot of different bosses and enemies to face giving another element of replayability to the game, SO MANY ITEMS and different combinations to discover, it is fairly well balanced, there is a clear progression from early game to end game, you will get a massive ego boost when you beat each end boss for the first time, it's great to play while listening to music and podcasts as it requires no extreme concentration for a majority of the game and has little dialogue.CONS- There are a few bugs graphically but nothing that will impact your enjoyment, it's addictingNEUTRAL- There isn't much in-game explanation but trial, error and googling will give you more than enough informationOVERALL- BUY THIS GAME AND WRATH OF LAMB! This is one of my favorite games of all time and I cannot wait for the remake that is slated for later this year.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 15, 2014
												In The Binding of Isaac, you play as a young boy of about 4 who, on the run from his demented mother who wants to sacrifice him to God, falls into a twisted basement full of grotesque and horrifying creatures whom he must fight...by crying on them.  In this game there is permadeath--no checkpoints; if you die you must start over from the beginning.  In  each procedurally generated floor, there are progressively greater numbers of rooms filled with progressively harder enemies.  Within these rooms you get pickup items such as bombs and keys, as well as collectible items that upgrade your character with such effects as increased fire rate, homing tears, flight, and many many more.  The enemies are varied and entertaining, the endless RNG ensures that no two runs are the same, and the selection of nearly 200 items will have Isaac finishing every run with a different look and different abilities.  This is an absolutely brilliant game with well-balanced difficulty, (that is, hard, but not rage-inducing Dark Souls-tier hard) tight controls, amusing art, and endless replay value.  Go ahead and spend the small price of five dollars.  I assure you you won't be disappointed.

												The Binding of Isaac is a Randomly Generated, Roguelike dungeon-Crawler game with difficulty being it's strong suit. This game will make you quit and rage on multiple occasions, but I gurantee to you this is worth it. Heck, even pick up the DLC if you've got the money to spare. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 2, 2014
												Take the original legend of zelda, a generous helping of heavy religious themes and overtones, internet culture and then throw political correctness out of the nearest window and put it all in a blender.  what you end up with is a truly great game where every single playthrough is completely random and unique from the items and powerups you find to the layout and enemies you find in each and every room you enter. half of the fun of isaac is never quite knowing what you're going to find or come across in that particular playthrough and finding new items and discovering what they do and how they combine with the other items you've discovered, the fact that your characters appearance also changes, sometimes drastically, depending on what you've found is another aspect that adds to the discovery of the game.in terms of negatives if you don't do well with bullet hell games then you will definitely find the later areas of the game challenging as it can be unforgiving, but rewarding, at times, also if you think you would take offence to the idea of a small child fighting off the corpses of his dead siblings with his own tears then you should probably give the game a miss lolbut overall i love the game, has become one of my favourites of all time and im just waiting for rebirth now.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2014
												A classic up there with the likes of Super Mario Bros. and Legend of Zelda (who it pays homage to). THE rogue-like of all rogue-likes and one of only four 10/10 games I have ever experienced (another of which is Binding of Isaac: Rebirth). If you haven't played this game yet, you owe it to yourself to give it a try. For the hours upon hours of replay value that you'll get from this game, you CAN NOT beat the price. Seriously. I have put in an easy 120 hours into this one alone not counting the other 100 hours I have invested in Rebirth so far (and I've just barely scratched the surface on that one).The game seems so simple the first time you play it. And then you play it again and realize it's like playing an entirely different game. And so on, and so on. There are just so many builds, unlockables and other variables, no 2 runs ever feel exactly the same. One of, if not THE most replayable game I've ever played.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 14, 2011
												It's not quite Dungeons of Dredmor--which is by far the better deal--but it is fun in its own right, mixing the most shallow the roguelike experience can offer with the most shallow of Zelda dungeon-crawling.  It works darn well as a pick-up-and-play title, with you either victorious (unlikely) or dead all under 20 minutes.  However far you get is largely determined by the luck of the randomly-generated draw: power-ups you get, health available, enemies you face.The perfect title if ye're lookin' for a time-killer.  You'll probably never see all the collectables and secrets the game has to offer.

content:
Posted: October 3, 2011
												This is one of my favourite indy games to come out this year. Binding of Isaac gives the experience of dugeon crawling from early Legend of Zelda games, with procedural generated content being a major factor. Rooms, enmies, bosses, and items are all randomly generated for every play through, which makes for incredibly unique experiences every time you play. The glaring issues with this title seem to all be represented on the technical side of things: deleting temporary browser data /still/ wipes part of your save file,  no steam cloud support, limited control configuration (no gamepad support). Gribes aside, Binding of Isaac offers hours of arcade-like entertainment with high replay value, all for a mere $5.

Posted: September 30, 2014
												Binding Of isaacI got this game a copple of days ago after watching it for a long time on live streams and youtube!I absolutly love this game to HELL(Or the basement), The binding of isaac is a indie game made by Edmund MCmillen(also made Super meat boy) and Florian himsl. The binding of isaac (BoI for short) is a roguelike indie "Dungeon crawler", Where you the player(Isaac) needs to escape to the basement and escape the wrath of your own mother.The controlls are super easy to use you use W,A,S and D to walk and the arrow keys to shoot... and space to use your item(space bar itemsThe game and controlls are easy to pick up and play but REALY hard to master. If you like zelda dungeons then you will 100% like this game.The gameplay focuses on isaac that needs to go trough dungeons fighting of rooms of monsters and getting "Uprades" to get stronger(and make look isaac MORE stupid every item you pick up).Along side isaac there are more chacters to unlock, that need different things to be unlocked. 1 for example needs you to have a lot of money and the other to have a lot of hearts.Binding of isaac is targeted to a more mature part of the audienceThe visuals in the game are good enough for a game like this and item and monster sprites are REALY well done, The only problem you may have are some item descriptions are not correct and some items not work.The reason for that is that BoI is made on a flash engine so sometimes laggs on good computers, or things not work properly, and its realy diffecult to patchBinding of isaac is a great game to play and the DLC makes it even more beter with new versions of monsters, Items called"trinkets" New items and even more bosses and to top it all of 2 whole new area's to fight 2 very strong bossesThe binding of isaac is a great game to buy and just play a ton of or play for a hour and lay it down(or just die on the first level and just trow your computer out of the window)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21, 2014
												I've played 300+ hours of The Binding of Isaac. If anyone's qualified to talk about this game, it's people like me. I love this game so much that I bought the $40.00 on-disc copy. Now, without further ado, let's get down to brass tacks. TBoI is a randomly-generated "rougue-like" heavily inspired by games such as The Legend of Zelda, which happens to be one my all time favorite franchises. The items you acquire on each new and different run alter both your playstyle and your appearance, forcing you to adapt to new strategies and find new ways to overcome your foes. All of these elements combine to create one of the most complete packages I've ever seen in a game. Tack on a DLC that doubles the content and a remake on the horizen, and you've got the best game $5.00 (or $1.24) can buy.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 22, 2012
												For me, one of my all time favorite games was Legend of Zelda on the NES.  Binding of Isaac takes the feel of that original cartridge game and gives it a scatalogical overhaul.  With a difficulty level approaching some of the toughest platformer and shooting games I've ever played, it's a serious game despite it's immature slant.  The randomly generated dungeons lead you to earning meta-acheivments, meaning each time you play you aren't necessarily playing to win, but to unlock something for your next run.The randomness of the game is a feature and also highly frustrating.  Sometimes you get bad items on the first level or two, and you just know you have no chance to win that run.  Yet you reset the game and keep playing. Ultimately I find myself booting this game up more then any other steam game though.  Despite it's difficulty I can play it for five minutes or five hours and I'm always treated to a great experience.   If you don't have Binding of Isaac yet, you're missing out.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 14, 2014
												Isaac comes to in the upper level of the basement and you, the player, must guide him through the dangers that lurk below. The UI is very similar to what you’d expect from an early Zelda title. You have three heart containers. Three counters keep track of your amount of coins, bombs, and keys. The dungeon layout is shown on the upper left and your current items are listed next to your heart containers. You start out with only your tears to fight off the grotesque creatures of the basement. Each floor of the basement is littered with a slew of enemies, chests, items, a treasure room, and a boss room. Upon entering a room, all of the doors will lock until every enemy in it has been defeated. You can blow open a door, but it will cost a single bomb. Useable items can often be found in chests, but are also dropped from enemies. These could be tarot cards, pills, or some other miscellaneous item. Where as the tarot cards have a specific use, pills have random uses. These range from incredibly useful to potentially harmful, so consume them at your own risk. Treasure rooms are marked by their gold outlines, and within them lies a single power-up. These power-ups can increase your speed, change your projectile type, increase your max HP, etc. Some power-ups are weak and their effects can leave more to be desired, while others can be complete game changers and turn the tide of battles in your favor. They’re creatively designed and include some pretty outlandish things like a pair of high heels and even dog food. They also change your physical appearance, and seeing as they stack infinitely, this can result in some pretty hilarious or gruesome appearances. As you progress throughout the game, Isaac’s exterior begins to reflect the hell that is the basement. There are a plethora of bosses and they all battle in different ways. Defeating a boss will open a trapdoor to the next level, and between each floor of the basement a cutscene plays that shows Isaac having a nightmare, often of him being publicly embarrassed. The cutscenes, although oddly humorous, add little depth to Isaac’s character as it can be assumed that the events he worries over never actually took place, seeing as some are pretty over-the-top, such as one where he dreams he was being pooped on by a group of people. The final boss is no other than Isaac’s mother. And even after you’ve managed to beat her, your adventure still isn’t over. There still remains another set of levels and a whole mess of enemies, secrets, items, and power-ups to find.Through and through, The Binding of Isaac is a bonafide roguelike in every sense of the term. Every dungeon is randomly generated, resulting in no two runs feeling exactly the same. You’re given simple controls and absolutely no tutorial of any sort. Like any self-respecting roguelike, this is a game of trial and error, and it isn’t afraid to hand you your behind on a silver platter. The staggering amount of enemies will force you to adapt to any situation, and you’ll find yourself dying often before you’ve learned most of the enemies’ maneuvers. Bosses deal a lot of damage fast and some will even spawn smaller enemies around themselves. Even after you’ve learned the behavior of every enemy in the game, you’ll still find yourself dying quite often. Useable items and power-ups add variation to the gameplay and the tactics you’ll use in combat. With the unbelievable amount of depth found in the seemingly simple game, The Binding of Isaac produces an experience that becomes insanely addictive and rarely feels stale, even after dozens of hours of playtime.The Binding of Isaac’s visual presentation is something straight from the mind of a madman. Its art style is sleek, simple, and endearing. The various brown hues of the basement stand apart from each other, enhanced by the excellent shading, but they’re just pieces in a whole that create an immersive and beautiful environment. The story is primarily told through Isaac’s drawings. It’s all nice and cutesy, that is until you actually walk around and see the dreadful conditions of the basement. A myriad of deformed and bloody enemies stalk the rooms and each seem to spout blood like a fountain upon dying. There are these worm-like enemies that actually look somewhat adorable, until they charge at you with their fangs bared, trying to eat your face off. Piles of poop lay scattered on the ground. The changes that accompany the power-ups can be humorous, but others completely change the way Isaac looks, essentially turning him into one of the monsters that he faces. The fact that you aren’t alone suggests that you aren’t the first to face the wickedness of Isaac’s mother, and the possibility that the enemies could be related to him makes the adventure even more cringe worthy. In some dungeons you’ll find a room in which you can purchase items in exchange for coins. Each of these shops feature a hanging Isaac-lookalike, their faces twisted with expressions of despair. It’s an enthralling visual endeavor that shocks you from the start and carries out its dark themes with precise execution.The Binding of Isaac’s soundtrack aims to emphasize the same contrast brought about by the art style, and it manages to do so quite well. The music is slightly upbeat and detracts from the hopelessness that Isaac feels as he wanders through the basement. At times the music speeds up just a bit and the volume increases, ramping up your adrenaline at the same time. There is a slight feeling of loneliness in the unknown created by the soundtrack, and this is where it slightly fractures the contrast and actually melds with the setting. Enemy and projectile sounds are squishy in nature, but impactful overall. The contrast between the game’s dark themes and relatively uplifting music is genuinely interesting and adds another layer of depth.Despite its numerous references and tie-ins to other forms of media, The Binding of Isaac does plenty to set itself apart from the pack. There are some really laughable moments in the otherwise grim depths of the basement: there’s a certain enemy that will scurry away from you, whimpering as it tries desperately to flee; of the hanging Isaac-lookalikes in the shops, one of them has a huge grin on his face; some of the items and power-ups are just meant to make you burst out laughing, like Mom’s Pad – a useable item that makes all enemies in a room retreat for several seconds. Also, it raises some very serious questions that most games wouldn’t dare ask. It ventures into often-untraveled territory by challenging our understanding of organized religion, mental illness, and child abuse. These are very touchy subjects and it’s admirable to see developers who aren’t afraid to speak on them. The Binding of Isaac proves to be a unique and addictive adventure. Its humor is welcoming and its roguelike nature results in an unbelievable amount of replay value. While it may look simple at first, there is a surprising amount of depth to be found. Its endearing art style and aesthetically pleasing soundtrack is welcoming, while its dark themes are perfectly executed in the story and character designs. More than just a fun game, it questions what we as a society perceive to be norms and challenges us to think differently. The only real downsides to the game are the lack of characterization on Isaac and the slight capitalization on nostalgia. Aside from that, it’s an incredible game that should be played by anyone who enjoys a solid roguelike – or just a good game in general – because it stands head and shoulders above its competition in the genre.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22, 2014
												Okay, I guess since this is the most played game I have on my library, I've got some things to say about it. First of all, the game can be really hard on new players, but within a few hours you'll find yourself dwelling deeper into the depths of the basement (literally). The randomness of rooms, enemies and items you get each time really adds up for the replay, which is basically infinite. You feel challenged, sometimes a little unfairly, but most of the times, you're the only responsible for your success or defeat. It's very hard to put into words how much I enjoy playing this game. Each time you beat the game, it expands even more, and there's also challenges to complete, secrets to find, endings to discover, and to top all of that, a huge set of achievements to unlock, which will take your time very good. So, if you want a game that it's challenging, time-consuming and addictive, you can't go wrong for such a small price. And be sure to get the Wrath of the Lamb DLC as well.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												This is THE game.Now, for me discovering ang getting into Isaac was totally a suprise. I normally like games with outstanding artwork or very beautiful story or an amazing combination of both; basically what you could call: light, easy (maybe more women-orientated) games. BUT, Isaac has nothing to do with that and even so it has become one of my favorite games ever.It is dark, very simple and straight-forward (from minute one you control you character a 100%). You move: up, down, left, right.You shoot: up, down, left, right. (you shoot tears, how sad is that)Also you have two other commands: bombs, and special items. And there you go, trying to survive in a basement full of♥♥♥♥♥♥ spiders and worse things to suprise you, looking for your mother so you can kill her before she kills you. What I really like of this game is that there is not only one ending. You have to finish it over and over to get new items, achievements, characters and more difficult levels. But it doesn't get boring (or at least nor for me) as it changes continously and it is always unpredictable. After months of playing to Isaac I am about to get all the achievements (it might take me another month) and I hope by then they release the second part. It is going to be awesome.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 7, 2014
												The Binding of Isaac. So much I could possibly say about it. Let me start off by saying I have played this for about a full 2 days time (48 hours) and I have loved almost every second of it. Now that that is out of the way let me state the reasons I like it and a couple of things that I want in Rebirth. By the way I'm also talking about the DLC for this game in the review also so make note of that.Positives:The Graphics. The graphics in this game are just great.The items. The game has so many items, there are still probably a ton I haven't found.The difficulty. The game is purely skill based. The only time luck is involved is what you will get from rerolling and the slots.The enemies. Sure you got flies and spiders which aren't that great, but then you delve deeper and find all sorts of horrors.The creativity. The game just oozes creativity.The story. I just like the story.Negatives:-Lemon Mishap and Wiggle Worm. These are two items I just can't stand. Lemon Mishap spawns are small circle around you which makes you move slightly faster. Wiggle Worm makes your shots move around like the Medusas in Castlevania, usually missing your enemies.-No save mechanic. I understand that it was made in flash, and that saving will be in Rebirth, but I'm just warning you.-Sometimes you need a bomb to get a bomb. This is just a little pet peeve but in some rooms a bomb is surrounded by rocks, which means you have to use a bomb to get a bomb. It's just pointless and wastes time. Sometimes it's a double bomb which is fine because you gain, but sometimes it's a single bomb.That's about it. I would give it a 9/10. It's an extremely creative and fun dungeon crawler. Every game is different and requires skill. I would reccomend you buy it, and if you like it, maybe even Rebirth. By the way if the creator of Rebirth is reading this please don't change the graphics. I've seen what the new ones look like and I just really prefer these ones. I'm still going to get it regardless though.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 12, 2013
Cry or DieA former shell of a boy turned lump-of-flesh, Isaac must endure the horrors of lost siblings that never came to be. These undead fetuses are hellbent on destroying Isaac's very way of living and are very angry, that is to say, not only at him but at his mother even more so. Mom receives a godsend message from the Lord one day, asking her to prove her devotion and faith by sacrificing her son, Isaac. Who knows if his late brothers and sisters suffered the same fate, but one thing's for certain, Isaac isn't going to wait to find out!Overall, the top-down arcade style of The Binding of Isaac is great fun to be had. The levels are generated at random each time, and knowing this, makes for high replay value... from an indie game no doubt! Enemies are unique in appearance, there are various items with special capabliities, and plus, you take down your foes by crying a surge of tear drops! Poor Isaac... more fun for us then!

												This game is one of the greatest games I have ever played. It sort of reminds me of old school Zelda dungeons mixed with Super Meat Boy (but that's just because it's the same creator which gives it the same art style). This game literally has an infinite replay value. It takes a little while to get used to it, and may require a lot of practice, but there is a MAJOR feeling of gratitude once you kill mom (you'll understand once you play it). And if you think it stops after that, you are painfully wrong. There is a DLC that EVERYONE should buy day one. It makes the game nearly impossible to beat...nearly. This game deserves all the praise it reseves. 10/10, definetly buy. Plus, it's like 5 bucks, that's practically nothing for an unlimited amount of fun!

												The Binding of Issac is an awesome dungeon crawler where you play as Issac who tries to escape his mom who was told by God that Issac was overwhelmed by sin and to kill him. Issac escapes and must make it out of the dungeon with many monsters and powerups on the way. This game is very bloody and gory, however, it is alot of fun and very intense. It all goes around the bible and has many references torwards it. Also, you can become the devil, grow wings, shoot blood instead of tears, I know right, and beat the game with multiple characters. There are secret rooms, deals with the devil, is randomly generated, and has multiple bosses.I reccomend this game to anyone who can take blood and gore and not easily be offended by ammount of references torwards the bible. I rate it an 8/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 13, 2015
												The Binding of Isaac is a twin stick shooter roguelike. You play as Isaac, a little boy trying to escape his ridiculously religious mother that believes god wants her to kill her son. So he runs into the basement, going deeper and deeper, to escape her. You can move in eight directions and fire in four directions. You go through a series of square rooms similar in style to that of a Zelda dungeon from NES. You fight enemies in the rooms and get rewards for doing so. You might find keys for opening doors and chests. You might find bombs for blowing up rocks, walls, or enemies. You might find coins to spend in shops. And you might find shops, treasure rooms, or treasure chests filled with secondary items, powerups, or just some more health. There are a few unique rooms like challenge rooms where you get treasure for fighting some waves of enemies. Some rooms let you sacrifice a random amount of health for a power up. Some rooms even let you trade your total permanent hearts for powerups. These powerups are the main draw of the game, as they can change your stats and give you any number of strange powers or passives. It's tough and you're going to die, but death just means you get to start fresh and see what kind of new things await you in the randomly generated game. There are even a few characters to pick from and a series of challenges you can try out. PLUS a big batch of DLC in one great package to add even MORE things into the random mix of fun.This game suffers from its randomness. It's certainly the appeal, but if you get dealt a bad hand of powerups then you just have to deal with it. Lots of skill can make up for it, but sometimes it feels very unfair because it's random. It's troublesome to go grab for a powerup only to have it actually power you DOWN instead. Also, the tears you shoot can be hard to aim because they have a bit of an arc to when they are in the air and when they land, which isn't the easiest thing to gauge in a top down 2D environment. Hitboxes can also be a bit hard to tell sometimes due to the rounded, somewhat squishy style of the characters. Also... while the game does direct you to the program suggested for making controller support, there's not controller support in the game itself. Why not just add in controller support in a later patch? That's a minor annoyance but... it's annoying.The thing that makes this game so great is that you can play it over and over and over again and it's different every time. There's so much content here for the price of 5 bucks it's insane. It's an amazing buy for one of your first Steam games, especially on a budget because there's lots here. And the DLC is reasonable if you want even more content. The challenges and characters and item combinations all make for endless possibilities. Your run can take five minutes or two hours. There are multiple endings too so the replay value is through the roof. I can't recommend it enough. The Binding of Isaac gets an 8 out of 10. I hear Rebirth is good... maybe I'll be able to play it someday.
