number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 22, 2012
												For me, one of my all time favorite games was Legend of Zelda on the NES.  Binding of Isaac takes the feel of that original cartridge game and gives it a scatalogical overhaul.  With a difficulty level approaching some of the toughest platformer and shooting games I've ever played, it's a serious game despite it's immature slant.  The randomly generated dungeons lead you to earning meta-acheivments, meaning each time you play you aren't necessarily playing to win, but to unlock something for your next run.The randomness of the game is a feature and also highly frustrating.  Sometimes you get bad items on the first level or two, and you just know you have no chance to win that run.  Yet you reset the game and keep playing. Ultimately I find myself booting this game up more then any other steam game though.  Despite it's difficulty I can play it for five minutes or five hours and I'm always treated to a great experience.   If you don't have Binding of Isaac yet, you're missing out.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
												I'm not a fan of horror, I also get nauseous easy and panic easily. Binding of Isaac since it's debut was a game I mentally boxed as something other people with stronger mental fortitude play. It's creepy and disturbing, with a disarming art style and hearing the story second hand (And knowing the roots of Abraham and Isaac) did intrigue me but also made me uneasy. The Winter steam sale gave little more incentive for at least buying it, but I wouldn't recommending waiting for another sale, this game is immensely fun.There's a few games that walk, and talk like a horror like Gregory Horror Show and their ilk, which did put me off initially easily became a cult-classic, and this outclasses 'bubblegum goth' genre for quirky horror games. The game has little in way of a tutorial, and even less explanation of what every item does, but part of it's charm is exploration in a dark basement of the unknown and working things out for better or worse. Each run and level is randomly generated to keep you on your toes, there's various items that will help deal with the hideous enemies of Isaac's long-begotten and far less loved (or Lovely) siblings, of which they are legion and twisted in their variations. The game also while simple to grasp, does involve a deal of strategy later on; particularly when you find you can make a deal with the Devil for items that could turn the tide of your misfortune. Other more common rooms make such promises, that you'll need to crawl through a spiked door way to get to. Some items affect your primary weapon, which is a gag in itself, that you fight through the waves with your own tears. Give the game a simple test run, and you'll understand why this has unlimited ammo. The items also affect Isaac visually, and accumulating into making him just as horrifying as the abyss around him, and to be helpful: Even if you look like a Demon's Spermatozoa decked in black membrane with long, sharp gnashy teeth touching enemies will still kill you. I still have no idea why I thought I could eat them, .. but apparently this form gives me flight to get over ledges.Still Enjoy.

content:
Posted: September 19, 2014
 "Without hesitation, he flung open the hatch, (...) and threw himself down into the unknown depths below." A kind of game that I(and probably a lot of other gamers) really like- a game where it has great gameplay, combined with deep and great story.The entire story is a satire about a bible story The Binding of Issac, where Abraham tried to sacrifice his son Issac because he heard(or thought he heard) a voice from the God. The Binding of Issac(video game), BoI for short, has a similiar story, but is set in a more modern setting.Issac(not that Issac from before) and his mother(name not revealed) lived in a small house. While Issac played with his toys, his mom watched Christian broadcasts from the TV. One day, his mom thought she heard a voice from the God, and he ordered her to kill Issac to prove her devotion. Issac, heard all of it and tried to escape. He found a trapdoor to his basement, and the game begins with him jumping down to it.McMillen wanted to show the positive yet the nagative affects of the game's developer Edmund McMillen had from the Scripture. McMillen makes a lot of dark humour and satire based games, and most of his creativity with the story of those games came from his Catholic mother and grandmother, and he thanks them for that. But his Christian dad was harsh on him, saying that playing games such as Magic: The Gathering and Dungeons & Dragons will lead him to hell.McMillen tried to tell this bible's positive effects and nagative effects on a child. It is very interesting, and it is even more so that even though 3 years have passed since the launch of this game, a solid explanation to the game's story hasn't been found yet. This was intended, as McMillen wanted this game to have many interpretations of it's endings, just like the Scripture.Now, to the gameplay aspects- it's a roguelike with some real-time aspect, combined with basic Legend of Zelda dungeon structure. The game has insane replay values, with over 100(or 200) items in the game, and 70(or more) of them is all stackable. You can trie out new combos with different enemies and bosses, such as combining a rapid fire laser weapon with a item that lets you charge, or combining a item which lowers your range but increases your damage with a weapon that inscreases your range.The game is lot like Zelda in this aspect where you don't know what things does until you try them out. The game also drops you bombs, keys, coins and health in various rooms, which is much like Zelda as well.The soundtrack is amazing, Danny Baranowsky did a fantastic job. It's one of those soundtracks that you would download to your phone or iTunes.This aspects makes this game really addicting, with you always telling to yourself "What will I get this time?". These games that makes you excited everytime you launch your game is a proof of a great game.The Binding of Issac definitely deserves an 8/10- it's a great game. I saw people saying this game is bad because it's too 'hard'. But that's the core mechanic of the game, you need to retry and see what happens next time. That's the general concept of a rogue-like. Some says that this game's only fun is it's item-combining aspects, but that's not true. If you look deeply into it's story as well, you will find it very interesting. The game's fun also comes from not only the Zelda aspects, but also from the rogue-like aspects.Unfortunately, The Binding of Issac is not a masterpiece(9/10). I want it to be, but I just feel like there's something missing here. Maybe it will be a masterpiece in The Binding of Issac: Rebirth, a remake to this game, which will not be made in 3 mouths. Yay.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 8, 2013
												The Binding of Isaac is an amazing game that mixes elements from The Legend of Zelda dungeon crawling all the way to games like Minecraft with it's randomization. In the Binding of Isaac, you play as a small boy called, Issac who is chased down into the basement of his house due to his Mother believing that she is hearing the voice of God.      You can collect many different types of Weapons in the Binding of Isaac. Ranging from arrows, to bombs, to stranger things such as ipecac, to brimstone, to chocolate milk! There more items than just weapons. You can collect things that will aid you on your journey such as dog food (Additional health), and Pyro (You grow fuses in your head that give you 99 bombs). There is a great diversity of items in the game and it is very unlikely that you will get the same items in next playthroughs.     Now, all of these items don't mean much if the combat is bad. And it is not. Rooms are randomly generated and there is quite a selection of enemies to fight. All the enemies in the game serve a specific role to play. There are not many different types of bosses however in the game, which does mean that you repeat a boss that you fought in a previous run.     All in all, the binding of isaac is a great dungeon crawling game and plenty of randomization to make each run different.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												"If there are two people who I believe are going to save hardcore gaming, it's Hideki Kamiya and Edmund McMillen."-SelfCreated behind the same mind that brought you Super Meat Boy, The Binding of Isaac is a randomly-generated dungeon crawler with light rpg elements present and constant action. Set in a twisted atmosphere with dark themes ranging from child abuse, gender identity, suicide, abortion and how religion might negatively affect a child, you play as Isaac; a child who is relentlessly being hunted by his mother, who believes her son is corrupted by sin and must sacrifice him to prove her love to her god after hearing his voice. The game can be brutal at moments, due to not knowing how the game is played and randomly generated levels. However, the longer you play the game, the better you will understand how the game is played and where secrets are placed, what the items do and attack patterns your enemies display. It instructs you with trial and error gameplay and it's random but understandable level design. This is easily one of the best designed games I've ever played, and look forward to the remake of this game.Since this is a flash game,however, expect to have random framerate crashes, as the game is packed with so much content there will be moments where the game will slow down and may even stop responding.If you are a fan of the NES Legend of Zelda dungeioneering and/or a challenging game with a test of wits and reflexes, this is for you.

content:
Posted: November 20, 2014
												Well, considering I recently logged my 100th hour, I figured I would write a review.What can I say about this game? Well...anyone who asks me, I tell them that it's the wierdest game you'll ever see. Perhaps that's not entirely true, but it's rather close.Isaac is a rouguelike that is probably the hardest game that I've ever played. It's incredably frustraiting to simply play it for fun, but thankfully the game has nice tiers of bosses to defeat, and some bosses are just simply rewarding to kill due to their difficulty.Anyone new to the game will die, and any veteran will die often as well. The game is unforgiving and, as I said, incredibly difficult. One aspect that I don't like is it's heavily RNG, but the game does kinda adress that once you've beat it a few times *cough10-15cough*I honestly don't know why I still play it. I think it's because the challenge itself allures me, and the fact that I have 100 hours there's still so much to do. The game has a few gates requiring you to beat it again in order to proceed, and that's what i like about it. If you don't like difficulty, anger, and death, don't buy this. But if you're willing to struggle through and recieve the great feeling of awesomeness when you succeed after 200 runs, then this is for you.

content:
Posted: January 16, 2015
												Okay here's what I got from the plot so far:You are an young boy who gets bullied a lot, your dad left you and your mom is neglecting you to watch christian broadcast. Due to the religious background that your mom instilled in your education, you are having trouble setting borders between reality and fiction, but you manage to stay sane by focussing on drawing. However, when mom gets a vision (which can be explained by the pills in her purse you find later) she locks you up in a room without anything to do (including drawing), which slowly drives you to insanity. After mom gets her last vision she will try to murder you, but you manage to escape moms psychotic rage by jumping into the hatch to the basement. The basement is a representation of your fears, in which you have to cry away the monsters, geneticly manipulate your body and mind, make a pact with the devil, and face your fears, so you are ready to kill your mother at the end of your insane quest.But at what cost will you survive,,,?10/10: Fun for the whole family

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 1, 2014
												The Binding of Isaac looks and feels like a flash game; something you could play for free online. It looks like someone had an idea, said "hey, wouldn't this be cool?" and made it.But if you can get past that, The Binding of Isaac is surprisingly thorough. It's a Roguelike - you die, you start again. You gather items and powerups in order to ramp up your character and clear the dungeon. And boy are there a lot of items; it wasn't until at the very least my fifth playthrough that I started to see repeats at all, and according to the wiki, there are dozens of things left to discover.That being said, there's no way to see what some of these items actually do before using them. The tarot cards which are usually one-time effects have consistent effects through all playthroughs, but there's so many of them it's hard to remember. There's multitudes of passive collectables you could potentially find which end up helping you create a 'build', and you never know what you'll get (or what they even do, if they require an activation).Despite finding multitudes of what I thought were "broken OP" items, the difficulty in this game is fairly high, and despite at least twenty attempts, I've only managed to beat the game once. And like any Roguelike game, exploration, while rewarding, is extremely dangerous! Unlike a game such as FTL where you are encouraged to finish every encounter you can in order to build up enough power, Isaac's hard limit on healing items forces players to rethink trying to explore the entire dungeon, and for once, NOT exploring can sometimes be the tactical choice.The game produces mountains of tough little choices. Do you permanently lower your health for a good item? Which active ability is best to keep, since you can only have one? Do you go through the spiked door where you will take guaranteed damage for a shot at loot? Do you use your key on the chest in front of you, or is there a shop down the road that can help you unload cash?Unfortunately, these decisions are sometimes uninformed. Again, without a way to see what an item does before picking it up, experimentation is required. This can be painful when you are asked to pay a health container or two before even figuring out what it does, or you activate something that teleports you, or some other unexpected event.If you can handle the sort of gross nature of the environment, this is a Roguelike which'll keep you busy for a few hours.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
												The Binding of Isaac is a  Roguelike [en.wikipedia.org] Adventure game similar to the Legend of Zelda. Each run the player is confronted with a randomly generated arrangement of rooms containing a wide variety of enemies and traps. Each stage is completed by defeating a boss that has unique abilities. Throughout the run your character becomes stronger by acquiring upgrades. Once dead you have to start back at stage one meaning there is minimal progression outside of becoming more skilled and unlocking more items.The Binding of Isaac is an excellent example of a well executed modern Roguelike, although you may consider waiting for The Binding of Isaac: Rebirth which will free the game from the limiting Flash engine which is one of Isaac's biggest flaws.

content:
Posted: November 16, 2014
												Randomly generated good times full of disgust, horror, and a few really good chuckles. If you like raunchy comedy, and you like video games The Binding of Isaac has got what you want. In this game you play foremost as Isaac. A poor child who has been shut away from all worldly pleasures and is about to be sacrificed. All thanks to Isaac's mother who hears voices. Voices of what she believes is God telling her to do these things. Which is an obvious reference to the story of Isaac from the Bible in the 22nd Chapter of Genesis (Hey now you know). In the game you retreat from your bloodthirsty mother into the basement (the entrance to which is located convieniently in Isaac's room). There you will fight against the demons that haunt the house using little but your own tears (no really his weapon is crying) and your ablility to dodge moderatley fast enemys and projectiles. Learn the secrets, make a deal with the devil (or two), collect the power-ups, and confront your mother for your very life.Pros:+One of the most strangely addicting games I've ever played+Replay value is immense+Funny (for the right audience) and packed full of references to pop-culture and internet memes+Doesn't take a powerful computer to run it (most laptops should be able to handle it even)+Totally affordable at $5. (Personally I got it on sale with the dlc for under a dollar)+Soundtrack is notably well done. A lot of love went into the score of this gameCons:-It's got a fairly steep learning curve-Luck can be a defining factor-Sometimes it can become unreasonably offensive to the more sensitive audience (I personally like the humor but I know people who I would not show this game to) All in all I'd give it a solid 85/100

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2015
												The Game "The Binding of Isaac" is very good and a bit difficult that it's one of the favorite indie games since Super Meat Boy (Which is made by the same person).  If you choose Maggy after you defeat MOM using the character Isaac that it's unlock, you get 4 heart containers and a heart you carry can restore 1 heart meter.  the MOM boss is only part like eyes, a leg and hand (that you need to stay away).  this is basically combined The legend of Zelda, And Robotron 2080.  My favorite Boss is Monstro who barfs drops of blood which can hurt you and jumps high and lands down, splattered blood all over the place. Isaac's weapon is only tears that you need to kill enemys to pick up coins to buy, bombs and keys even pills that cause diarrhea, or restore your heart meter.  Don't forget training cards! the trading cards are very useful to warp places, getting items and defeating enemies.  The giftshop is use to buy items using pennies that you have like a stepladder, books and hearts.  The arena stage is that you can enter that you have a full HP, If you open the chest and you get the items, enemies will pop out and you need to kill it.  Keys are used to open doors, chests and blocks. The special door that holds a special item that you need to upgrade tears, damage, rage, and speed even special attacks.  Bombs are use to blow up walls for secret rooms that lots of pennies, Boulders for bridges and enemy barriers.  That's why my rating for this Indie/Adventure game is 8.7/10.  Thanks for Reviewing for this game.  Bye                                                                                                                                           KirbyMaster16 :)
